title: WebGL skinning animation
body: I am trying to run the "webgl - animation - skinning" example with various other animated .js models in place of the "animated buffalo" provided--all to no avail with the same error re.
"THREE.js Animation Handler/line 351" and "Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'name' of undefined"--any suggestions/ideas?
Thank you.
How did you get these models?
Only buffalo has skeleton and skeletal animation.

Thank you for your quick response/ I now see (from your question and then looking at the animated buffalo.js file versus the horse (animated).js file and some of my own simple animated models) that these are very different scripts, indeed.

I was under the misconception that since I rigged a simple armature w/bones in Blender and was able to export to .js that this would be the same as "skeleton/skeletal"--So I use "morphTarget" insteadfor these?
and then is it possible to generate the "skinned" models via Blender?
Is there an advantage?
I really appreciate your help and patience towards a "noob"!

-----Original Message-----
>From: AlteredQualia <reply@reply.github.com>
>Sent: Dec 27, 2011 12:08 PM
>To: ge5 <ge5@nyu.edu>
>Subject: Re: [three.js] webGL_animation_skinning (#962)
>
>How did you get these models?
Only buffalo has skeleton and skeletal animation.

>
>--- 
>Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
>https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/issues/962#issuecomment-3283104
> So I use "morphTarget" insteadfor these?
Yes.
> and then is it possible to generate the "skinned" models via Blender?
Only as morphs.
It doesn't matter how animations are generated in Blender, everything gets converted to morphs on export.
>  Is there an advantage?
Advantage is exactly this, all complexities of skinning / rigging are lost on conversion, only vertex positions matter for morphs.

Also morphs are very fast on playback

Disadvantage is that morphs are only suitable for relatively small meshes, as every keyframe needs all vertices.
Also you can't really do easily procedural animation.

body{font-size:10pt;font-family:arial,sans-serif;background-color:#ffffff;color:black;}p{margin:0px;}wow-thanks; that is really helpful info / clarifies a ton (i am coming from actionscript 3 + papervision...) so, would you recommend MD5 format in Blender to try to work on "procedural" animation /interactivity?
(i need to stick to Blender)--but then how would i export to JSON loader?

-or don't i need to convert ?Again, your help is deeply appreciated.-----Original Message----->From: AlteredQualia >Sent: Dec 27, 2011 6:19 PM>To: ge5 >Subject: Re: [three.js] webGL_animation_skinning (#962)>>> So I use "morphTarget" insteadfor these?

Also morphs are very fast on playback>>Disadvantage is that morphs are only suitable for relatively small meshes, as every keyframe needs all vertices.
Also you can't really do easily procedural animation.>>--- >Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:>https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/issues/962#issuecomment-3286503
Oh, that's hard to read.
I suggest not to use "reply-by-mail" feature, only use web interface.
In Blender you can use whatever you want, just your animations will be exported as morphs.

Also you could use Collada, it does support skinning, but just as a way of having smaller files, upon loading to three.js it's anyways converted to morphs for playback (in `ColladaLoader` there is software skinning which bakes frames into morphs).
As I understand from above Blender exporter generates only morph targets.
So what are the tools to create models with bones that can be used with Three.js ?
could you point me to some demos of skeletal animation in three.js ?
( other than the buffalos)

title: fix test warnings
body: This commit fixes a few warnings when running the tests.
* In Active Record for @cesario's fix in #inspect last week, when `@attributes` is not defined.
(M) * In whiny_nil, where it's not useful to stub object_id of nil.
@dmathieu the whiny_nil looks good but I would fix the @attributes one by ensuring that @attributes is set to nil (or an empty hash) rather than using defined?
check.
actually no, I can't use .nil?.
It wouldn't remove the warning.
@dmathieu that is not what I meant.
Usually when variables are not defined, the proper fix is not to add a defined?
() check, but ensure that both initialize and initialize_copy are initializing the variable (in this case, @attributes).
My fix is to -make  SURE- `MyModel.allocate` can be inspect.

(M) So we don't call
`initialize` or `initialize_copy` at all.

We cannot sanity check cases because people are writing case ruby.

title: groonga: add missing dependency on PCRE
body:
since groonga 2.0.6, it detects PCRE automatically, but OSX's system PCRE
is not compatible with it.
We need homebrew-installed version of PCRE.
Reported by @kou
Thanks for the report.

title: making PCRECache a LRU cache
body:
This patch make s PCRECache a LRU cache and introduces a new runtime option
Preg.CacheLimit which specifies the maximal number of cache entries per thread.
The latter point fixes a Wordpress issue where the PCRECache was growing indefinitely.
Is it posible to merge it to master?
We are having an issue with growing PCRE cache and have to restart hiphop daemon every 2 hours.
Is this still a problem?
the PCRE cache is now shared between threads so it's no longer duplicated across all threads.
We're closing out all bugs older than 2 months.

http://www.hiphop-php.com/wp/?p=575

If this is still an issue, please re-open it, and in order of goodness:

1.

Give detailed repro steps
1.

Write a test case in hphp/tests/quick (run it with hphp/tests/run) and send the pull request
1.
fix it in a pull request

body:
Hello

I installed the newest version after having stopped using sparkleshare for a while because of issue https://github.com/hbons/SparkleShare/issues/1170.
Now I installed version 1.1 and run it using the same git repos (without resetting the prefs, what a bad idea indeed).
I got constant notifications of conflicts telling me "not to worry" since some copy would be kept.
Looking at the sparkleshare folders I realized that some recent work is now gone.

I'd like to know how to get it back...

looking at the git log gives me the sad impression that nothing has been kept... and is rather old, although sparkleshare (v1.0) has run many times since then.

insteadit seems that new work is seen as old work to be deleted...

the data should still be there.
it probably derailed off the master branch and committed changes there.
`git reflog` should show the lost commits and you can get them back by `git checkout $hash`

title: Suspend-resume in AIO can cause a readPendingException
body: When a read completes in AioSocketChannel and the newly read buffer is advertised via fireInboundBufferupdated(), user code can trigger a ChannelHandlerContext.readable(false), followed by a ChannelHandlerContext.readable(true).

The ChannelHandlerContext.readable(true) causes a new AioSocketChannel.beginread() call to occur, in this case immediately because we are on the event loop thread, then the fireInboundBufferupdated() method returns, and the read completion handler calls AioSocketChannel.beginread() again.
This second call to beginread() causes the java.nio.channels.readPendingException.
@jfallows merged your pull request..
Thanks again1
Awesome.
Thanks @jfallows!

title: fix HttpContentDecoder (broken in 4.0.0.Final)
body: modify HttpContentDecoder to writeInbound and readInbound from it's internal decoder.
The EmbeddedChannel contains a decoder, which works on inbound data.
I -found- this problem specifically with some tests that I have that start a server and validate that HttpContentDecompressor works correctly, it has stopped decompressing as of 4.0.0.Final.

Thanks,
 Derek

title: problem with mapping collections in LINQ
body: Hi, Automapper has problem with projecting collections in mapped object.
It throw exception with message: Sequence contains no elements.

Hi, here's another discussion of this issue: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/10291879/automapper-fails-when-projecting-iqueryableobject-when-object-has-a-collection

As "nemesv" points out on stackoverflow: It seems Mapper.createMapExpression currently does not support:
 - generic collections of value types e.g.
List<string> etc.
- arrays of complex types or value types e.g string[], Bar[] etc.
Even then, you can't mix MapFrom with Project.To - since those can't be read by query providers anyway.
Unfortunately.

title: Cannot execute mysql "LOAD DATA INFILE" query after using verify_active_connections!
body: *Imported from Lighthouse.

(M) * Original ticket at: http://rails.lighthouseapp.com/projects/8994/tickets/6266
created by **Ngan** - 2011-02-17 06:48:05 UTC

Hi, I'm on Rails 2.3.8, but I think this problem affects Rails 3.x as well.
After using ActiveRecord::Base.verify_active_connections!
after the mysql going away, or even a manual disconnect, I cannot seem to do a "LOAD DATA INFILE" query.

I get an error from MySQL: "ActiveRecord::StatementInvalid: Mysql::Error: The used command is not allowed with this MySQL version"

Yes, I have checked permissions and what not.
I can do the LOAD DATA INFILE before the reconnect.

To duplicate, simply boot up console:

<code>
> ActiveRecord::Base.connection.disconnect!
> ActiveRecord::Base.verify_active_connections!
> ActiveRecord::Base.connection.execute("LOAD DATA INFILE '/tmp/some_file.txt' INTO some_table")
*Imported from Lighthouse.

*
Comment by **Ngan** - 2011-01-08 07:24:40 UTC

<code>
   > ActiveRecord::Base.connection.disconnect!
> ActiveRecord::Base.verify_active_connections!
> ActiveRecord::Base.connection.execute("LOAD DATA INFILE '/tmp/some_file.txt' INTO some_table")
*Imported from Lighthouse.

*
Comment by **Ngan** - 2011-01-08 08:19:10 UTC

Actual console output

```
ruby-1.8.6-p399 :003 > ActiveRecord::Base.connection.execute("LOAD DATA LOCAL INFILE '/tmp/test.infile' INTO TABLE users")
[Sat Jan 08 00:09:29 2011] (9990)   SQL (1.7ms)   LOAD DATA LOCAL INFILE '/tmp/test.infile' INTO TABLE users
 => nil 
ruby-1.8.6-p399 :004 > ActiveRecord::Base.connection.disconnect!

=> #<Mysql:0x104c6f890> 
ruby-1.8.6-p399 :005 > ActiveRecord::Base.verify_active_connections!

[Sat Jan 08 00:09:58 2011] (9990)   SQL (0.2ms)   SET SQL_AUTO_IS_NULL=0
 => {…connection stuff…} 
ruby-1.8.6-p399 :006 > ActiveRecord::Base.connection.execute("LOAD DATA LOCAL INFILE '/tmp/test.infile' INTO TABLE users")
[Sat Jan 08 00:10:00 2011] (9990)   SQL (0.0ms)   Mysql::Error: The used command is not allowed with this MySQL version: LOAD DATA LOCAL INFILE '/users/Ngan/Development/streamsend/ngan.infile' INTO TABLE users
ActiveRecord::StatementInvalid: Mysql::Error: The used command is not allowed with this MySQL version: LOAD DATA LOCAL INFILE '/tmp/test.infile' INTO TABLE users
	from /users/Ngan/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.8.6-p399@streamsend/gems/activerecord-2.3.8/lib/active_record/connection_adapters/abstract_adapter.rb:221:in `log'
	from /users/Ngan/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.8.6-p399@streamsend/gems/activerecord-2.3.8/lib/active_record/connection_adapters/mysql_adapter.rb:323:in `execute'
	from (irb):6
```
*Imported from Lighthouse.

*
Comment by **Jonathan Monahan** - 2011-01-10 10:28:36 UTC

Is the --local-infile option commented on here http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.0/en/loading-tables.html relevent?
*Imported from Lighthouse.

*
Comment by **Jonathan Monahan** - 2011-01-10 10:48:15 UTC

...and probably this too: http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.1/en/load-data-local.html
*Imported from Lighthouse.

*
Comment by **Ngan** - 2011-01-10 22:27:19 UTC

I've gone through all the MySQL documentation and made sure everything has permissions.
You'll notice in my console output, the first I do the LOAD DATA LOCAL INFILE, I am able to do it just fine.
It is only after the reconnect that it has the error.
BTW, I tested this further and it's only happening for LOAD DATA LOCAL INFILE, not LOAD DATA INFILE.
The LOCAL is key.
*Imported from Lighthouse.

*
Comment by **Jonathan Monahan** - 2011-01-11 09:11:03 UTC

Note at the bottom of http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.1/en/load-data-local.html, the last comment details how to configure client and server to always allow LOAD DATA LOCAL INFILE.
Yes LOCAL is key - it *has* to be enabled explicitly because otherwise it is a security risk to MySQL.
As for why it works initially, and not after a reconnect, I have no idea other than that the connect is clearly enabling it, whilst the reconnect is not.
(M) I'll leave that to someone more knowledgeable about ActiveRecord, MySQL AR adapter, MySQL gem (or is it mysql2 you are using), mysql client libraries, etc.
*Imported from Lighthouse.

*
Comment by **Ngan** - 2011-01-11 18:04:44 UTC

I'm using Rails 2.3.8, so it's on the mysql gem (not mysql2).
I've also updated to the latest gem version of mysql, and still get the same problem.
*Imported from Lighthouse.

*
Comment by **Jonathan Monahan** - 2011-01-13 13:29:20 UTC

We are running Rails 2.2.1 with the mysql gem, but I believe I have fixed the problem by adding

    @connection.options(Mysql::OPT_LOCAL_INFILE, 1)

in `mysql_adapter.rb` in `connect` at line 555 or anywhere before the call to `@connection.real_connect`.
Note also #1797 which fixes the `:reconnect` option if you are running Rails < 2.3: basically you move the line that sets `@connection.reconnect` after the call to `@connection.real_connect`.
We are in the middle of upgrading to mysql2 gem, so I will confirm that the change also works there.
*Imported from Lighthouse.

*
Comment by **Ngan** - 2011-01-13 19:34:50 UTC

Awesome!
I confirmed that it fixed it for me as well.
Any case someone can make  a patch for this?
Jonathan, do update on how it goes with mysql2.
Thanks!
*Imported from Lighthouse.

*
Comment by **Jonathan Monahan** - 2011-01-13 23:18:10 UTC

Yup, this also works with the mysql2 gem.
*Imported from Lighthouse.

*
Comment by **Ngan** - 2011-02-11 23:15:01 UTC

Is this happening for anyone else?
*Imported from Lighthouse.

*
Comment by **Ngan** - 2011-02-16 19:41:50 UTC

here's a patch that I did in my Rails app to fix this:

``` ruby
module ActiveRecord
  module ConnectionAdapters
    class MysqlAdapter
    private
      def connect_with_local_infile
        @connection.options(Mysql::OPT_LOCAL_INFILE, 1)
        connect_without_local_infile
      end
      alias_method_chain :connect, :local_infile
    end
  end
end
```

title: forgery protection in master
body: *Imported from Lighthouse.

* Original ticket at: http://rails.lighthouseapp.com/projects/8994/tickets/6674
created by **Anton Topchii** - 2011-04-05 20:58:29 UTC

Current forgery protection is not raise any exceptions as said in documentation.
It just quietly reset session.
And request processing goes to controller action.

# CSRF protection is turned on with the <tt>protect_from_forgery</tt> method,
  # which will check the token and raise an ActionController::InvalidAuthenticityToken
  # if it doesn't match what was expected.

A call to this method is generated for new
  # \Rails applications by default.

You can customize the error message by editing
  # public/422.html.

def verify_authenticity_token
        verified_request?

|| handle_unverified_request
      end

      def handle_unverified_request
        reset_session
      end

A warning had been added recently: https://github.com/rails/rails/commit/59705deeaf3861caff1016e59da47708870f33ba

@josevalim This can be closed.

title: [AsseticBundle] inotify support for --watch option in assetic:dump command
body: Using inotify the command does not need to busy wait for changes in any of the files defining formulae or containing assets anymore.
It configures a number of inotify watches and reacts only once a change has been performed.
What about having this a core feature of Symfony.
We have quite a few places where it can be used.
In fact, all the component using the Config/Loader and Config/Resource classes.
What do you think?
Yeah I thought about that, could just build some generic watch mechanism from this.
It could be very useful as Symfony component with fallback to old 1-sec watching mechanism (when inotify is not available).
Many other libraries will benefit from it.
like, phpunit or Behat.
Can i help somehow on this?
Any news on integrating some sort of generic inotify support into the core?
Are you guys thinking about something like a `kernel:watch` command that fires events when things change?
I wanna create new `FileWatcher` component, which we will be able to integrate into Finder, Config/Resource and others.
I can do it till friday if you don't mind?
Feel free.

title: forgery protection in master
body: *Imported from Lighthouse.

* Original ticket at: http://rails.lighthouseapp.com/projects/8994/tickets/6674
created by **Anton Topchii** - 2011-04-05 20:58:29 UTC

Current forgery protection is not raise any exceptions as said in documentation.
It just quietly reset session.
And request processing goes to controller action.

# CSRF protection is turned on with the <tt>protect_from_forgery</tt> method,
  # which will check the token and raise an ActionController::InvalidAuthenticityToken
  # if it doesn't match what was expected.

A call to this method is generated for new
  # \Rails applications by default.

You can customize the error message by editing
  # public/422.html.

def verify_authenticity_token
        verified_request?

|| handle_unverified_request
      end

      def handle_unverified_request
        reset_session
      end

A warning had been added recently: https://github.com/rails/rails/commit/59705deeaf3861caff1016e59da47708870f33ba

@josevalim This can be closed.

title: -found-ation 4:Tabs Not working When Base Href Set
body: When base href is set, the tab works but then it always redirect to the index of the base href set.
I'm using -found-ation-4.0.9 but the problem has been present in all v4.x versions so far.
Do you have an example?
I'm not sure what you mean.
Is the same problem described in #1146 and #405

here is how to reproduce:

Set  `<base href="http://example.com" />` inside your `<head>` section.
create a file inside a subfolder of your webroot with a standar tabs sections.
Let's say the file is accesible via  http://example.com/somedir/file.html.

```

Section 1

Content of section 1.

Section 2

Content of section 2.

``` If you click any tab you are redirected to http://example.com.

If you modify your links to be `

Section 1

` then you are not redirected but tabs don't change on click.
@Stolz I'm not seeing the issue in -found-ation 4.1.6 if I use fully qualified links.

`

Section 1

` appears to be working for me.
The point of setting base tag is precisely not having to use fully qualified links.

If it works for you in a different scenario then great, but what I have reported here is using base tag and relative links, which AFAIK is HTML/XHTML/HTML5 fully compliant and it's also how it appears in your docs.
You already fixed it in previous versions so it should be easy to address it again.
I respect you don't want to fix it again but at least the docs should clearly say only absolute links are supported for sections.
I really don't understand Zurb policy for closing bugs.
It's the second time in a few days that I report something and the issues got closed because "it works for me in an scenario that has nothing to do with what you have reported".
here I talk about an standard compliant and very common scenario and in bug#2376 I only used code extracted from **your own docs and files** to prove the problem.
It make s me wonder the point of reporting things.

title: [Session][2.1.8] New PHPSSID after user logged in
body: I'm using `PdoSessionHandler` to store my session in the database.
With an empty session table, I'm accessing my application home page, this create a record in the database and set the `PHPSSID` cookie value.
All good, if I refresh the page or browse public pages I still have the same `PHPSSID`.
Now when the user is logging in, the user is ending up with a new `PHPSSID` and another record is created in the database.
My question is: Why the existing `PHPSSID` of the user is not used and the session updated?
Why a new `PHPSSID` is created?
it's the same user.
It means that each time a user is accessing the application, 2 records are created in the database whereas one should be enough.

Cheers,
Maxime
@drak Can you explain this behaviour?
Is it meant to work like this?
This is expected behavior and having session regenerated when you log in make s a session fixation attack harder.
This is intended as @mvrhov has explained.

title: add a sanity check for Volume.update()
body: In recent testing, I -found- that Eucalyptus 2 did not honor having a volume id passed to DescribeVolumes.
It accepts the request, but always returns all volumes.
since boto blindly takes the first element from the list of volumes returned, this means that calling update() on a volume object can completely change which volume is being referenced by the object.
This patch changes the behavior, so that only data for the volume id requested will be used.

title: Only check AttributeID collisions if system property is set
body: fix for https://github.com/harrah/xsbt/issues/329
The check is there to give a better error message than a ClassCastException, which is likely to result.
This patch is a temporary workaround that works in some cases (I assume it works for yours), but not in general.
A proper fix needs to do conflict management across builds and ensure each plugin is only loaded in one class loader.
It is rather complicated, unfortunately.
#329 is the main blocker for 0.12.0 right now.

title: adding a child page fails with postgres
body: After creating a simple cms project according to the instructions in the development documentation, I add two pages via the admin: a root page and then a child through the 'add child' button in the page list.

After saving the child page, I get the following error:

> ValueError: cache_tree_children was passed nodes in the wrong order!

> full stack trace here: https://gist.github.com/1015683

After a little poking around, it seems like the problem originates in cms/admin/change_list.py line 78:

> pages = self.get_query_set(request).drafts().order_by('tree_id', 'parent', 'lft').select_related()

which seems innocuous enough at first glance, but gives different results on Postgresql.
This is because nulls come at the end of ascending sorts, rather than the beginning like in mysql or sqlite, for example.

since root nodes have parent=null, we find that, on postgres, this puts the root nodes last in order, which causes an error in a later call to mptt.cache_tree_children

I'm using the 'develop' branch of django-cms, Django 1.3, Postgresql 8.4.7
Related wontfix django ticket: https://code.djangoproject.com/ticket/13312

title: [WIP] JSON encoder refactor
body:
# Primary goals

- [x] use the stdlib `json` gem to generate JSON insteadof stitching strings together
- [ ] Maintain backwards compatibility (`encode_json` support) by moving the old encoder into a gem
- [x] Avoid significant performance degradation in JSON generation

## Secondary goals

- [x] Have a pluggable JSON encoder API for alternative encoders (which the old encoder gem and third-party json libraries can use)
- [x] Clarify the role of `as_json` (e.g.

re: circular-dependency detection, walking recursive data-structures, see discussions in #11460)
- [x] Integrate @sergiocampama's code from #11728
- [ ] Move `as_json` core extensions under core_ext: Track #12203

### Nice to have

- [ ] Remove unnecessary tests?
(most of them are testing `encode_json`, we should just trust the `json` gem for these?)

- [ ] Speed up JSON encoding (relative to before this change)
- [ ] A guide article explaining the new JSON encoder design & API

### Misc TODOs
- [ ] *Remove all `#to_json` code in the rest of Rails, use `#as_json` instead
- [ ] Review all `#as_json` definitions (e.g.

String#as_json should be #to_s insteadof self, TrueClass#as_json should return true insteadof self, Struct should pass options to the hash object, etc)
- [ ] Ask: fixing json version to [>= 1.7.7](https://github.com/flori/json/blob/master/changeS#L11-L19)
- [x] Bug: encoding Activesupport::SafeBuffer causes infinite loop
- [ ] Figure out what to do with [this](https://github.com/rails/rails/commit/72f37bd8bc5b3beb1e8a2d1ac2de2c045cd0cfd2) ([bug](https://rails.lighthouseapp.com/projects/8994/tickets/5655)), and people who overrides `to_json` in gerenral

- [ ] Get more people to vet this
- [ ] http://hashrocket.com/blog/posts/faster-json-generation-with-postgresql / https://github.com/JackC/json_api_bench


/cc @jeremy @tenderlove

(M) Some quick notes on the design (as of the current iteration) (TODO: turn this into a guide):

`as_json` is an API intended to be consumed by JSON encoders as little "hints" on how to represent that object JSON.
If the programmer -CHOOSE- to implement a custom `as_json` method on your objects, you are free to return *any* Ruby object.
In other words, you are *not* responsible for ensuring the object you return from `as_json` is 100% jsonified (contains only the equivalent of JSON primitive types, i.e.
(M) `Hash`, `Array`, `String`, `Numeric`, `true`, `false`, `nil`), nor are you responsible for recursively calling `as_json` on any embedded objects.
however, if you -CHOOSE- to return non-jsonified values, it is up to the encoder to decide how it should encode these values.
(M) This also means that you cannot rely on `some_object.as_json == JSON.parse(some_object.to_json)`.
If you are consuming the return value of `as_json` in your code, and you are not writing a JSON encoder, you are probably doing it wrong.
The guarantee provided by `as_json` is probably much weaker than you think.

Preliminary perf test, round 1:

Basic test cases in encoding_test.rb repeated 100,000 times

```
master (aeef940): 34.644668s
branch (0f7d16a): 42.632916s
```

23% slower :neutral_face: :neutral_face: :neutral_face: :neutral_face: :neutral_face:

[Profile](https://gist.github.com/chancancode/5d5ce205f05b56483cdb) <- For the same trivial workload used in the first test
[Profile2](https://gist.github.com/chancancode/486ef4f6dc9ac607ae1b) <- For slightly less trivial workload, this is currently 30% faster :heart: :heart: :heart: :heart: :heart:

`gem 'rails', github: 'chancancode/rails', ref: 'aeef940'` vs `gem 'rails', github: 'chancancode/rails', ref: '0f7d16a'`

title: Move management of the locale from the Session class to the Request clas
body: (M) The locale management does not require sessions anymore.
In the Symfony2 spirit, the locale should be part of your URLs.
(M) If this is the case (via the special `_locale` request attribute), Symfony will store it in the request (`getLocale()`).
(M) This feature is now also configurable/replaceable at will as everything is now managed by the new `LocaleListener` event listener.
(M) It does break BC as `getLocale()` moved from Session to Request.
The configuration for the default locale is now also done on the framework entry insteadof the session one.
Any thoughts?
(M) I guess this is the proper thing to do in terms of following the concept that an URL identifies a resources and not some value in a session.
I should have noted that if a session is present, it is used; so the behavior is backward compatible.
It's good move, but we also should consider to "rework" remebering locale using headers (cookie - #2240) if session is not started/defined.
@stloyd: Ticket #2240 will be closed when this PR is merged as it fixes reporter concerns.
What do you mean by "headers"?
In this patch, the locale is stored in the URL, and there is no need to store it anywhere else.
@fabpot I saw this that is stored in URL, but I'm not sure that this could be always used.
About "headers" I was meaning cookies (i.e.
`$request->cookies->set('_SYMFONY_LOCALE', $this->defaultLocale);`).
We should consider this that developers sometimes cannot change already existing URLs to add just locale... Or I'm missing something and this is available somehow ?

title: Leaking file descriptors when using asynchronous stdin STREAM
body: Hello!
Please, look at this code example.
I've tested it on Centos 6 and Ubuntu 12.04 using current master branch of Tornado.

```python
from __future__ import print_function
from tornado.gen import Task, Return, coroutine
from tornado.ioloop import IOLoop
import tornado.process
import os


STREAM = tornado.process.Subprocess.STREAM


@coroutine
def call_subprocess(cmd, stdin_data=None):

    sub_process = tornado.process.Subprocess(
        cmd, stdin=STREAM, stdout=STREAM, stderr=STREAM
    )

    if stdin_data:
        yield Task(sub_process.stdin.write, stdin_data)
        sub_process.stdin.close()

    result, error = yield [
        Task(sub_process.stdout.read_until_close),
        Task(sub_process.stderr.read_until_close)
    ]

    raise Return((result, error))


@coroutine
def main():

    pid = os.getpid()
    cmd = ['ls', '/proc/%s/fd' % pid]

    for i in range(100):
        yield call_subprocess('wc', stdin_data="123\n")
        result, error = yield call_subprocess(cmd)
        print('num of fds:', len(result.split('\n')))

    print('process pid:', pid)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    ioloop = IOLoop.instance()
    ioloop.add_callback(main)
    ioloop.start()
```

On my machine output is something like:
```bash
...
num of fds: 107
num of fds: 108
num of fds: 109
process pid: 17548
```

File descriptors not closing and remain open which leads to leaking.
Or am I doing something wrong?
Sorry, I think I've provided a bad example because I use stderr  STREAM here.
I'll try to reproduce my problem in a correct way and will make  another issue or reopen this one.
I've updated issue description
The leak is in your test code:  you always pass stdin=STREAM, but you only call sub_process.stdin.close() if stdin_data is given.
If you move the stdin.close() call out of the if statement (or only pass stdin=STREAM if stdin_data is present), the leak is gone.
Oh, so obvious, but I missed that.
Thank you!

body: I am learning the ThreeJs examples and I try to write the examples of "canvas_interactive_cubes.html".
I use an parent objects to contain all the objects.

And it is working with similar code to "canvas_interactive_cubes.html", but if I update the code in render() to rotate the parent objects not by changing the position of camera, the position of intersects is not correct.

Shenghong

Not supported?

particle.position = intersects[0].point;

however, scaling in hierarchy is the only thing is currently not supported and it's what it's causing your troubles.
If you can avoid scaling by now all the better, otherwise... someday we'll tackle it!

title: The problem with the display of shadows. (customDepthMaterial)
body: Hi.
This is a problem in all versions THREE.js.
Good: http://clip2net.com/s/2xBiy.

add ball:

Bad: http://clip2net.com/s/2xBkJ.
I noticed that these problems prosihodit after adding new objects.
As well, this bugappears when skinning = true, at SkinMaterial.
I'm not good in GLSL but perhaps the problem with this: http://clip2net.com/s/2xBma.
I think that the texture as it confuse with a memory card, but it's just my personal ....

This bugis here: 

https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/blob/master/examples/webgl_animation_cloth.html#L205

It should be

    var uniforms = { texture:  { type: "t", value: clothTexture } };
fixed, thanks.
Again... http://clip2net.com/s/2xChZ , http://clip2net.com/s/2xCiE and http://clip2net.com/s/2xCjj bugUV.

uniforms = { texture:  { type: "t", value: mesh.material.map  } };

mesh.customDepthMaterial = new THREE.ShaderMaterial( { uniforms: uniforms, vertexShader: vertexShader, fragmentShader: fragmentShader } );
You'll need to tell us more, from this it's hard to tell what's going on.
The best would be if you could post a link to live demo somewhere.

http://213.219.244.158/rinok/?DAE=prilavok1&sex=F

code in init.js
It did not work?

At the first sight it looks ok: shadows are being cast for alpha tested leafs so it seems `customDepthMaterial` is working ok.

What doesn't look ok is a direct rendering of transparent leafs.

insteadof being `transparent` they should be using `alphatest`:

```javascript
object.children[i].material.alphatest = 0.5;
```

Another thing, you should drop this UV scaling in custom depth shader:

```glsl
vUV = 0.75 * uv;
```

and just use straight UVs to have one-to-one mapping between direct rendering and shadows:

```glsl
vUV = uv;
```

In cloth example this was just a hack to make  shadow look nicer (to have less aliasing in the shadow because texture pattern has too much details for shadow).
Thanks a lot, it helped!
I do not want to be intrusive, but while you're here, I'll ask one more question.

http://clip2net.com/s/2xESo and http://clip2net.com/s/2xET0

shadowMapCullFrontFaces affect the appearance of the shadow.
Why is that?
customDepthMaterial.side = 2 does not change.
Don't use numbers, nobody will know what `2` means, that's why we have named constants.
Also your code will break if for any reason constant value would change.
(M) Anyways, `material.side` is ignored for shadows.
For casting shadows all objects are assumed to be solid from the point of view of light.
`renderer.shadowMapCullFrontFaces` flag then selects how depth map will be rendered.

By default with `shadowMapCullFrontFaces = true` a back side of the object is used (back of the inside of hollow object with cut away front side), when you set `shadowMapCullFrontFaces = false` then a front side of the object will be used (equivalent to regular rendering).
Both approaches create different artefacts, what's better depends on the exact use case.
So, I can not get the shadow of the back of the Plane?
*Front Plane
@alteredq I wonder if renaming `shadowMapCullFrontFaces` to `shadowSide` and have it default to `THREE.BackSide` would make  this more intuitive.
@mrdoob Maybe, I'm also not very happy about `shadowMapCullFrontFaces`.
just `shadowSide` is kinda confusing.
Maybe something like this?
What you can't have is having shadows from non-physical objects which are invisible from one side and visible from other side.
If object exists, it will cast shadow from all viewing angles.

> ```javascript
renderer.shadowMaterialSide = THREE.BackSide;
```

That one sounds good to me.
Ok, changed.
We'll see how it goes.
For the moment it felt weird, but it could be just old habit ;)
The term `shadowMaterialSide` is not clear.
Is it what you cull or what you don't cull?
I also do not think it is a good idea to use the same THREE constant for different purposes.

Personally, I think `shadowMapCullFrontFaces` was just fine... :-)

but..., if you prefer a change, how about something like this?

renderer.shadowMapCullFace = THREE.CullBackFace;

	THREE.CullBackFace
	THREE.CullFrontFace


Or,
	
	renderer.shadowMapCullSide = THREE.CullBackSide;

	THREE.CullBackSide
	THREE.CullFrontSide
	
And if you decide to support open meshes someday

	THREE.NoCulling
@WestLangley agreed, the more I think about it, the less I like the change (I'm also bugged by reuse of the constants, OpenGL does this and it's confusing).

Maybe like this:

```
renderer.shadowMapCullFace = THREE.CullFaceBack;

THREE.CullFaceBack
THREE.CullFaceFront
```

This would closely match the implementation.

Plus these constants would also make  for better API in `renderer.setFaceCulling` which now expects string constants `"front"` and `"back"` (somehow curiously OpenGL API also allows `FRONT_AND_BACK` option).

> ```
> renderer.shadowMapCullFace = THREE.CullFaceBack;
> 
> THREE.CullFaceBack
> THREE.CullFaceFront
> ```

That sounds good to me too.
I like it, too.
Ok, changed.
While at it, I also changed front face direction from strings to named constants.
We never used it, but at least now it should be consistent with the rest of API.

title: asset_host is ignored
body: Rails 4 ignores asset_host config option.

### Steps to reproduce

* create new Rails 4 app:
  
  ```
  mkdir r4 && cd r4
  rvm use 1.9.3@rails4-asset_host-test --rvmrc --create
  gem i rails -v '4.0.0.beta1' --no-ri --no-rdoc
  rails new .

```
* Uncomment `asset_host` option line in `config/environments/production.rb`
* make  your application stylesheet go through SASS: `mv app/assets/stylesheets/application.css app/assets/stylesheets/application.css.sass`
* Put the following code in your `app/assets/stylesheets/application.css.sass`
  
  ```sass
  .rails-logo
      background: image-url('rails.png')
  ```
* Run `bin/rake assets:precompile`
* Find compiled stylesheet in `public/assets/application-*.css` and see that there's no asset host in `background` declaration.

### Expected result

I expected it to work in the same way as in Rails 3.
You can use the same scenario with latest Rails 3 and it produces URLs with asset host in compiled stylesheets.
(M) have you tried `RAILS_ENV=production bin/rake assets:precompile`?
@rafaelfranca This one works with regards of asset_host.

title: Watch for double spends of wallet transactions
body: This pull adds ScanForDoubleSpends to check incoming transactions for double spends of wallet transactions.

Flagged wallet transactions give the following warnings:
1) in RPC the transaction gets the "doublespend" property
2) todo later: Qt should highlight it as a possible fraud attempt
3) confirmations is held at 0 for 200 blocks to keep it from being spent

The 200 block hold is a protection against double spends during forks.
The client is normally oblivious to double spends in other forks because it only looks at the fork its on.
ScanForDoubleSpends can compensate for that weakness because it can detect double spends from other forks and put at-risk transactions on hold.
Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/200250740be43e27e9517a2fd37e4b016999f863 for binaries and test log.
This test script verifies pulls every time they are updated.
It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.

If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/current/
Contact BlueMatt on freenode if something looks broken.
That sounds pretty cool if it works (is not exploitable).
Looks like signature malleability will trip this up, e.g.
anyone can trigger this on anyone's transactions.
I love the idea of this.
The transaction malleability problem needs to be solved (it shouldn't count as a double-spend if the second transaction contains all of the outputs of the first).
And this should be combined with a "relay first seen double-spend" patch, so you have a good chance of actually seeing double-spends.
@gmaxwell - good catch, I'm working on a fix.

Unless you get nodes to relay double spends they see, this isn't going to work...

Also, insteadof hiding blocks until 200, the status should simply not be Confirmed until 200 more.
see how generated coins work (120 blocks before Confirmed) for example.
Now it ignores double spends if everything is identical except the sigs.
I think we probably don't want to allow different inputs for same outputs, because independent transactions can have identical outputs.

Take this transaction triangle...
T1: in=A+B, out=X  // thank you
T2: in=C+D, out=X  // more money, thank you
T3: in=A+C, out=X  // benign double spend?
...if T3 gets mined, then T1 and T2 can't.
@luke-jr Even without relaying double spends yet, this already works most of the time.
(M) If you have 20 connections, you have 20 chances to get the double spend.
If none of your peers gets the double spend, it probably didn't reach very many nodes.
It also scans transactions in blocks, so you know immediately if your transaction loses, insteadof wondering if it's staying at 0 conf because it just got passed over.
If there's a fork, it scans other fork's blocks too.
Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/d5936b83c818863b39c00ee2c843df72d1591bd3 for binaries and test log.
This test script verifies pulls every time they are updated.
It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.

If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/current/
Contact BlueMatt on freenode if something looks broken.
Nice!
I'm working on replace-by-fee code right now, so the changes you're making to the wallet code will be really useful as part of my patch.

You should make  your code a bit more sophisticated so that you only care about double spends if the amount of Bitcoins being transferred to you changes, IE any changed output that goes to an address in your wallet.
(assuming you didn't send the transaction yourself) That way you won't get false positives when the sender uses tx-replacement to add more fees to a transaction after the fact.
@jevonx Well, I'd want to allow changes like increasing fees (which might require adding a change output that wasn't there before.
I'd prefer it to be something like  "doesn't pay _me_ any less", can you suggest a reason to be more restrictive than that?
We should still not show _both_ of a benign double spend, but we should probably not penalize the one we are showing.
The current double spend rules are pretty simple.
Jevon's patch should be good as is (I mean conceptually).
Then later changing what happens on double spend can update this code as well.
bitcoinj has code that does something similar, though unfortunately I only ever unit tested it (and it's not really complete).
Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/f7fb98b3a6d5d6141d74164556ddc26f9089ba47 for binaries and test log.
This test script verifies pulls every time they are updated.
It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.

If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/current/
Contact BlueMatt on freenode if something looks broken.
jevonx, could you rebase and squash your commits?
There are several now and a few are fixups for others.
It'll be a bit easier to review then.
@jevonx Poke, please rebase and squash...
Looking at this, the methods really don't belong on CTransaction either.
Feels like they should be part of the wallet.

title: add support for testing locale
body: would it be possible to add a testing locale to the LOCALE_NAMES dict in tornado.locale?
Facebook provide the "English (Upside Down)" locale for such a purpose (I believe).
I've seen other sites provided an "English (Pirate)" locale, ie "en_PR".
load_translations probably shouldn't be so strict with the LOCALE_NAMES check (load_gettext_translations doesn't do this check at all).
The whole LOCALE_NAMES list is a little weird; there's no real reason for something like that to be in the library.

Slightly longer-term, I'd like to add a locale that does automatic pseudolocalization for testing purposes, like http://google-opensource.blogspot.com/2011/06/pseudolocalization-to-catch-i18n-errors.html
Ok, thanks Ben.
In that case I'll hold out for pseudolocalization.

title: No <article> and no <section>
body: Why are "article" and "section" tags not used but "div" tags with id "container" and "main" ?

You can refer here

http://html5doctor.com/you-can-still-use-div/

The HTML5 doctors correctly wrote:
"You should use "div" when there is no other more semantically appropriate element that suits your purpose."
well I agree with you akuckartz, I might also go so far as to say there shouldn't be anything in the body tag at all.
I don't think we can assume everything made with boilerplate is a document.
It's designed to be flexible enough for applications as well.
So I'm very hesitant to add any additional structure within `<body>`.
I would like to point to someone's work that guides people on how to appropriately and effectively use HTML5 semantics.
Does anyone have a recommendation of a single document/article/post that tackles this?

http://html5doctor.com/glossary/
http://diveintohtml5.org/semantics.html

These are the two references and sites that I use when I'm looking for a refresher, or just to see what a specific tag is meant to be used as.
Thanks.
I'll add http://diveintohtml5.org/semantics.html#new-elements and the glossary to the resources section.

title: Repository -> Network -> 502 Bad Gateway
body:
Hi there,
i try to access the repository-branch-graph, but i get an 502 Bad Gateway error.

here are the gitlab logs:

==> production.log <==
Started GET "/repository123/graph" for 127.0.0.1 at 2012-07-09 16:55:13 +0200
Processing by ProjectsController#graph as HTML
  Parameters: {"id"=>"repository123"}

==> unicorn.stderr.log <==
E, [2012-07-09T16:55:15.321898 #24108] ERROR -- : reaped #<Process::Status: pid 24367 SIGKILL (signal 9)> worker=1
I, [2012-07-09T16:55:15.537042 #24408]  INFO -- : worker=1 ready

==> /var/log/nginx/gitlab_error.log <==
2012/07/09 16:55:15 [error] 25175#0: *26302 upstream prematurely closed connection while reading response header from upstream, client: MYIP, server: git.MYSERVER.COM, request: "GET /repository123/graph HTTP/1.1", upstream: "http://unix:/home/gitlab/gitlab/tmp/sockets/gitlab.socket:/repository123/graph", host: "git.MYSERVER.COM", referrer: "https://git.MYSERVER.COM/repository123"
i don't see any useful information in your logs.
Thats because there are no useful logs :(
Okay, this is really the only log-entry which is produced, doesn't know what to do, is there some debugging switch somewhere?

Edit:
-found- the debug-llog configuration in config/environments/production.rb, but nothing in the logs which would help.
could it be that it crashes if some commit-user are not in the database?
Imported the repository via git-svn-migrate script, its a large repository with 20 branches.

==> unicorn.stderr.log <==
E, [2012-07-10T08:43:58.538612 #24108] ERROR -- : reaped #<Process::Status: pid 24289 SIGKILL (signal 9)> worker=0
I, [2012-07-10T08:43:58.754787 #11686]  INFO -- : worker=0 ready
Does this error appear immediately?
or after 30 seconds?
Its not the timeout, it appears immediately.
but I think i've -found- the problem.
seems like the server kills the worker-process because of insufficient memory.
Allocated only 1 GB to the server, but the graph-generation need more, huh?
in some small projects, the graph works.
but the big project has 2000 commits.
which ram-amount is recommenced?
Lucky me, its a virtual Server, easy to upgrade.
we are using server with 512MB.
It work really fast for us.
there is a limit in graph - only 650 commits are showing.

Thats a strange issue, I've run "sudo -u gitlab bundle exec rails s -e production" to test the behavior, then i opened the url http://git.mydomain.com:3000/myrepo/graph to see what happens, and then.....the process is gone.
could be a problem with linux vserver, not sure about that.
(M) try debugwith strace
solved the problem in an other way, removed ram limits for the vserver, problem seems to be linux-vserver, not gitlab

title: Get ahead/behind commits
body: `git_graph_ahead_behind` is cool.
You know what's cooler?
Getting the actual commits which are ahead/behind.
:metal:
In case nobody already started working on this, would an API like [this](https://gist.github.com/yorah/5255190) be acceptable/fit your needs?
Yep, that API looks :gem:
API looks fantastic.
Is creating a revwalk and doing two walks such a big annoyance that it's worth creating a new array type and exporting all its new APIs?
You can achieve the same with a few lines of code (where `array` is whatever nice-to-use native array type your language provides).
What make s me a bit uneasy is that the current `graph_ahead_behind` code doesn't use the revwalk functions.
This would mean one code path to get the ahead/behind count, and another code path to get the actual commits.

Aside from that, and from the potential performance discrepancies with the revwalk approach (which may not matter depending on what @joshaber intend to do with this functionality), I will be happy to close my PR if this is the direction we want to go to!

Linked (vaguely) to #1259

/cc @scottjg
(M) The performance difference isn't going to be something you'll notice unless you're dealing with disconnected branches often.
The second walk will basically be free, as you've already cached the objects and would only have to recalculate the merge base.

If you're getting the ahead/behind commits, there isn't much reason to ask for the number beforehand; you can just count (and `realloc` probably wouldn't be that expensive when you have to consider how much we have to read from disc if you need to call it repeatedly).

`graph_ahead_behind` uses the same algorithm as the revwalk, but at a lower level, as it doesn't need to give back any other information than the amount of commits that have been painted one way or another.
Revwalk goes further and actually tells you which ones they are.
Your code basically reimplements most of revwalk, but with a couple of lists insteadof an iterator.
Unless the revwalk variant presents some big problem, I'm not sure that the extra code and complexity would be worth it.
If the slowdown is that noticeable, we should insteadtry to make  the revwalk able to share its cache or other information with a different walk.

Maybe `git_revwalk_reverse` where you switch what you hide and show could provide us with a boost in speed, as we've already calculated where to stop (not sure if it'd be useful in more situations, but wouldn't hurt to try).
I think it's the age-old question of how high-level libgit2 should be.
I thought the original `git_graph_ahead_behind` was surprisingly high-level.
but `git_graph_ahead_behind` is also awesome because it's something I imagine consumers will want.
It seems unfortunate that each different binding would have to implement it themselves.
It feels weird to want to sidestep the revision walker, as it's what's meant to give you this kind of information and if it's not up to the task, we should fix it insteadof going around it.
`ahead_ahead_behind` probably looks higher-level than the implementation would suggest because git started doing it more recently for more commands.
All it's doing is short-circuiting actually returning the values and counting with the data we'd need to do the revwalk anyway.
How are you going to use the information given by whatever comes out of this?
Is a list all you're going to show/need or would you like to be able to show the graph as it is?
This isn't so much about how high-level it should be.
The revwalk (or something based on it) should also get a higher-level layer/part with history rewriting eventually.
I'm more worried about finding something that fits inside the library and is for more than a very specific need.

Returning the ahead-behind of two commits is straightforward, but the graph can be anything, and a list is just one way of representing that, with the problems that passing around a potentially large list has.
At the end of the day, I want to be able to ask questions of libgit2 without caring how it's implemented.
Rev walker, something else, whatevs.
If there's some other API later, `git_graph` can be updated to use that.
The ahead/behind question is something that will be common for people building git clients.
What commits does my remote branch have that my local doesn't?
Vice versa?
The revision walker is how you ask for what's between A and B and what lies between two commits is a graph, with a multitude of representations as a list.
`ahead_behind` is a way to short-circuit a lot of this when you don't care about the commits, but only the number.
In this case you do care about the commits so you need to walk down the graph and pull each commit into your application to show it in whatever way.

I don't quite get why looping over some array insteadof the revwalk iterator is such a big advantage when you need to process the data further in order to get the rest of the data like subject or author and pass it onwards to the UI toolkit.
That's fair :+1:

title: setHasoptionsMenu behavior
body: On older devices where AB is handled by ABS (Android 4.0.4) the menu is created right away when calling setHasoptionsMenu(true) from fragment's oncreate method causing possible NPE if the we rely on objects in oncreateoptionsMenu that are created later in oncreate.
On Android 4.2.2 the oncreateoptionsMenu is called AFTER fragment's oncreate.
ABS does almost nothing on Android 4.0 and up.

I have this stackTrace from sony Xperia pro running 4.0.4
java.lang.RuntimeException: Unable to start activity ComponentInfo{cz.eman.imes/cz.activity.TrafficActivity}: java.lang.NullPointerException
	at android.app.ActivityThread.performLaunchActivity(ActivityThread.java:1967)
	at android.app.ActivityThread.handleLaunchActivity(ActivityThread.java:1992)
	at android.app.ActivityThread.access$600(ActivityThread.java:127)
	at android.app.ActivityThread$H.handleMessage(ActivityThread.java:1158)
	at android.os.Handler.dispatchMessage(Handler.java:99)
	at android.os.Looper.loop(Looper.java:137)
	at android.app.ActivityThread.main(ActivityThread.java:4441)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invokeNative(Native Method)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:511)
	at com.android.internal.os.ZygoteInit$MethodAndArgsCaller.run(ZygoteInit.java:784)
	at com.android.internal.os.ZygoteInit.main(ZygoteInit.java:551)
	at dalvik.system.NativeStart.main(Native Method)
Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException
	at cz.fragment.traffic.ParkingListFragment.oncreateoptionsMenu(ParkingListFragment.java:189)
	at android.support.v4.app.Watson.oncreatePanelMenu(Watson.java:55)
	at com.actionbarsherlock.ActionBarSherlock.callbackcreateoptionsMenu(ActionBarSherlock.java:559)
	at com.actionbarsherlock.internal.ActionBarSherlockNative.dispatchcreateoptionsMenu(ActionBarSherlockNative.java:65)
	at com.actionbarsherlock.app.SherlockFragmentActivity.oncreatePanelMenu(SherlockFragmentActivity.java:165)
	at com.android.internal.policy.impl.PhoneWindow.preparePanel(PhoneWindow.java:407)
	at com.android.internal.policy.impl.PhoneWindow.invalidatePanelMenu(PhoneWindow.java:758)
	at com.actionbarsherlock.internal.ActionBarSherlockNative.dispatchInvalidateoptionsMenu(ActionBarSherlockNative.java:52)
	at com.actionbarsherlock.app.SherlockFragmentActivity.invalidateoptionsMenu(SherlockFragmentActivity.java:150)
	at com.actionbarsherlock.app.SherlockFragmentActivity.supportInvalidateoptionsMenu(SherlockFragmentActivity.java:156)
	at android.support.v4.app.Fragment.setHasoptionsMenu(Fragment.java:763)
	at cz.fragment.traffic.ParkingListFragment.oncreate(ParkingListFragment.java:104)
	at android.support.v4.app.Fragment.performcreate(Fragment.java:1437)
	at android.support.v4.app.FragmentManagerImpl.moveToState(FragmentManager.java:877)
	at android.support.v4.app.FragmentManagerImpl.moveToState(FragmentManager.java:1088)
	at android.support.v4.app.BackStackRecord.run(BackStackRecord.java:682)
	at android.support.v4.app.FragmentManagerImpl.execPendingActions(FragmentManager.java:1444)
	at android.support.v4.app.FragmentActivity.onStart(FragmentActivity.java:551)
	at cz.activity.base.BaseFragmentActivity.onStart(BaseFragmentActivity.java:161)
	at android.app.Instrumentation.callActivityOnStart(Instrumentation.java:1133)
	at android.app.Activity.performStart(Activity.java:4475)
	at android.app.ActivityThread.performLaunchActivity(ActivityThread.java:1940)
	... 11 more
You should call `setHasoptionsMenu` in `onActivitycreate` not `oncreate`.
Ok thx.
just of pure curiosity, is it officially documented somewhere that I shouldn't call it from oncreate?

Because on this page it says 

" In order for this method to receive calls, however, you must call setHasoptionsMenu() during oncreate(), to indicate that the fragment would like to add items to the options Menu (otherwise, the fragment will not receive a call to oncreateoptionsMenu())."
http://developer.android.com/guide/components/fragments.html
This caught me as well.
I was calling ```setHasoptionsMenu``` in ```onattach```, and my ```oncreateoptionsMenu``` was being called after ```oncreateView``` in Android 4.2.2, but before it on my 4.0.4 device.
Moving to ```onActivitycreated``` seems to be acceptable since it ensures that it is consistently called after ```oncreateView```
Yeah there's something racy going on here.
There are two other bugs tracking that raciness therefore I am closing this.
Stick with what works, though.

title: #2778 - make  thread names unique per system (for 2.1)
body:
The MonitorableThreadFactory.copy method does not take into account the
counter:AtomicLong field, which then always starts out at zero for every
new dispatcher; the PinnedDispatcher creates one dispatcher per actor,
hence resulting in identical thread names if used by multiple actors.
solution: add the counter to the case class’ arguments

title: Gitlab::ShellEnv is not thread-safe with GitLab 5.3
body: `Gitlab::ShellEnv` is using `ENV['GL_ID']`, but `ENV` is shared by all threads.
ENV['GL_ID'] is possibilly accessed by many threads simultaneously on `threadsafe!` environment.

I experienced trouble related this issue:

* When executing two or more Automerge request simultaneously, sometimes the push event's author are superseded by another user.
And I guess this thread-unsafeness also affects grack.
A possible fix will be changing `Gitlab::ShellEnv` not to use `ENV` and passing env variables to `Grit::Git` explicitly.
Thanks.

title: [DependencyInjection] $container property not set in createService()
body: instances returned by ContainerBuilder::createService should have the container set if they implement ContainerAwareInterface

Interface injection was possible in the early stage of Symfony but this has been removed because it harms the flexibility: people may want to inject another object implementing the ContainerInterface insteadof the main container.
If you want to inject the container, you can do it.
(M) Its id in the container is ``service_container``
Hi, and thanks for the quick response.
I know I can inject the container and, In fact, that's what I do.
So, I might change this issue to changing the visibility of createService() to protected to allow to override the method and add that code.
That's what I do in my fork, but it would be nice to not having to rely on patches for such a minor thing.
Obviously, if there is a better way of doing things I'd be keen to learn about that.
The problem is that createService is called in response to setting services on other services.
The result is that those, in turn, start using the set instances and then those lack the container (hope that make s sense).
So, I think I really need to subclass in order to inject in createService directly.
If your service does not declare it needs to have the container injected in it, why should it be injected magically ?
If one of your deps also need the container, it needs to also declare it needs it.

Right, so now we are getting somewhere :)
I though implementing that interface was enough?
So, does that mean the container is needed to be set same as other required properties, so either as call method or constructor argument?
In that case I'd rather stick with what I have.
Still, in that case having createService as protected would make  things a bit cleaner for me.
ta, mano

@DerManoMann As I said in my previous comment, interface injection has been removed before the stable release (even before the beta) as it is flawed: several implementation of the interface may want  a different object injected in them.
Injecting the container into your service works *exactly* the same than injecting any other service
Fair enough.
just out of curiosity - would asking for changing the method to protected have any chance of success?
mano
Fair enough.
just out of curiosity - would asking for changing the method to protected have any chance of success?
mano
Only if you provide a good use case for this.
(M) The issue when changing the visibility to protected is that we must then keep BC on the method as it becomes an extension point of the class.
Fair enough.
just out of curiosity - would asking for changing the method to protected have any chance of success?

mano

PS: Thanks for your time - feel free to close this issue unless there is hope to get this change done

title: Lion complaining about dubious file permissions when installing LaunchAgent
body:
Happened to me twice, once for postgres, once for mongodb

After brew installing pg and initialising the db, I proceeded to install the LaunchAgent:

```shell
$   mkdir -p ~/Library/LaunchAgents
$   cp /usr/local/Cellar/postgresql/9.0.4/org.postgresql.postgres.plist ~/Library/LaunchAgents/
$   launchctl load -w ~/Library/LaunchAgents/org.postgresql.postgres.plist
launchctl: Dubious permissions on file (skipping): /users/omarqureshi/Library/LaunchAgents/org.postgresql.postgres.plist
```
setting g-w on the LaunchAgent fixed it, similarly with mongodb

```shell
$     cp /usr/local/Cellar/mongodb/1.8.2-x86_64/org.mongodb.mongod.plist ~/Library/LaunchAgents/
$     launchctl load -w ~/Library/LaunchAgents/org.mongodb.mongod.plist
launchctl: Dubious permissions on file (skipping): /users/omarqureshi/Library/LaunchAgents/org.mongodb.mongod.plist
```

Permissions on mongod

```shell
-rw-rw-r--   1 omarqureshi  staff   848 28 Jul 23:07 org.mongodb.mongod.plist
```

Compared to

```shell
-rw-r--r--   1 omarqureshi  staff   910 27 Jul 23:49 com.apple.CSConfigDotMacCert-omaraliqureshi@me.com-SharedServices.Agent.plist
```

could the #write method set the appropriate permissions to silence Lion?
or could we change them post-write?
Might be safer to set permissions post write, for each formulae that writes the plist, does anyone agree?
Pardon my unix/linux ignorance, but is there a command you ran in order to allow this to run?
@omarqureshi  agreed, we should start updating formulae to do "chmod" on the plists.
@al3x-edge after the ``cp /usr/local/Cellar/postgresql/9.0.4/org.postgresql.postgres.plist ~/Library/LaunchAgents/`` you need to do a chmod g-w on the .plist
I've noticed this isn't the case for all LaunchAgents, MySQL / Redis seemed fine.
this worked for me: chmod 644 org.postgresql.postgres.plist
fixed in a840c4a17d2f35095eba954adf4f231559056c46

  # :mongoid (bson_ext recommended) by default.

other ORMs may be
  # available as additional gems.

require 'devise/orm/active_record'

  # ==> Configuration for any authentication mechanism
  # Configure which keys are used when authenticating an user.

By default is
  # just :email.

You can configure it to use [:username, :subdomain], so for
  # authenticating an user, both parameters are required.

Remember that those
  # parameters are used only when authenticating and not when retrieving from
  # session.
If you need permissions, you should implement that in a before filter.

config.authentication_keys = [:name]

  # Tell if authentication through request.params is enabled.
True by default.

config.params_authenticatable = true

  # Tell if authentication through HTTP Basic Auth is enabled.
False by default.

config.http_authenticatable = false

  # Set this to true to use Basic Auth for AJAX requests.
True by default.

config.http_authenticatable_on_xhr = false

  # The realm used in Http Basic Authentication
  # config.http_authentication_realm = "Application"

  # ==> Configuration for :database_authenticatable
  # For bcrypt, this is the cost for hashing the password and defaults to 10.

If
  # using other encryptors, it sets how many times you want the password re-encrypted.

config.stretches = 10

  # Define which will be the encryption algorithm.

Devise also supports encryptors
  # from others authentication tools as :clearance_sha1, :authlogic_sha512 (then
  # you should set stretches above to 20 for default behavior) and :restful_authentication_sha1
  # (then you should set stretches to 10, and copy REST_AUTH_SITE_KEY to pepper)
  config.encryptor = :bcrypt

  # Setup a pepper to generate the encrypted password.

config.pepper = "adf6bff8723a62745ed3fc167642534955b8728a0fd53f6781f424c0e12372076774b01ca33b8006f9a290c0623899e241ebb630d310bc81eec8e117f5390c31"

  # ==> Configuration for :confirmable
  # The time you want to give your user to confirm his account.

During this time
  # he will be able to access your application without confirming.
Default is nil.
# When confirm_within is zero, the user won't be able to sign in without confirming.

# You can use this to let your user access some features of your application 
  # without confirming the account, but blocking it after a certain period 
  # (ie 2 days).

config.confirm_within = 2.days

  # ==> Configuration for :rememberable
  # The time the user will be remembered without asking for credentials again.

# config.remember_for = 2.weeks

  # If true, a valid remember token can be re-used between multiple browsers.

# config.remember_across_browsers = true

  # If true, extends the user's remember period when remembered via cookie.

# config.extend_remember_period = false

  # ==> Configuration for :validatable
  # Range for password length
   config.password_length = 6..20

  # Regex to use to validate the email address
  config.email_regexp = /^([\w\.%\+\-]+)@([\w\-]+\.

After this
  # time the user will be asked for credentials again.

# config.timeout_in = 10.minutes

  # ==> Configuration for :lockable
  # Defines which strategy will be used to lock an account.
# :failed_attempts = Locks an account after a number of failed attempts to sign in.
# :none            = No lock strategy.
You should handle locking by yourself.

# config.lock_strategy = :failed_attempts

  # Defines which strategy will be used to unlock an account.

# :email = Sends an unlock link to the user email
  # :time  = Re-enables login after a certain amount of time (see :unlock_in below)
  # :both  = Enables both strategies
  # :none  = No unlock strategy.
You should handle unlocking by yourself.

# config.unlock_strategy = :both

  # Number of authentication tries before locking an account if lock_strategy
  # is failed attempts.

# config.maximum_attempts = 20

  # Time interval to unlock the account if :time is enabled as unlock_strategy.

# config.unlock_in = 1.hour

  # ==> Configuration for :token_authenticatable
  # Defines name of the authentication token params key
  # config.token_authentication_key = :auth_token

  # ==> Scopes configuration
  # Turn scoped views on.

Before rendering "sessions/new", it will first check for
  # "users/sessions/new".

It's turned off by default because it's slower if you
  # are using only default views.

# config.scoped_views = true

  # Configure the default scope given to Warden.

By default it's the first
  # devise role declared in your routes.

# config.default_scope = :user

  # Configure sign_out behavior.
# By default sign_out is scoped (i.e.
/users/sign_out affects only :user scope).
# In case of sign_out_all_scopes set to true any logout action will sign out all active scopes.

# config.sign_out_all_scopes = false

  # ==> Navigation configuration
  # Lists the formats that should be treated as navigational.

Formats like
  # :html, should redirect to the sign in page when the user does not have
  # access, but formats like :xml or :json, should return 401.

# If you have any extra navigational formats, like :iphone or :mobile, you
  # should add them to the navigational formats lists.

Default is [:html]

  # ==> Warden configuration
  # If you want to use other strategies, that are not (yet) supported by Devise,
  # you can configure them inside the config.warden block.

The example below

  #     twitter.options :site => 'http://twitter.com'

  #   manager.default_strategies(:scope => :user).unshift :twitter_oauth

end

title: [HttpKernel] ConfigDataCollector: add support for new Zend OPcache accelerator
body:
More information: https://github.com/zend-dev/ZendOptimizerPlus

This extension is compatible with PHP 5.2-5.5.
I'm using it with 5.5 and 5.4.
The PHP developers plan to Include this as opposed to APC in PHP 5.5 core.

http://php.net/archive/2013.php#id2013-03-21-1

This does not really have to do with Zend Optimiser+.
It has to do with the newly open sourced version, Zend OPcache.
I noticed a *similar* PR here https://github.com/symfony/symfony/pull/7087 but did not like that the unit test check for accelerators was completely removed.
I also do not consider it necessary to add more code just for an extension check (I would consider that 'unnecessary re-factoring').
And finally, I have no idea what the final purpose of it is.

Based on its title, it seemed like at first that it was for Zend Optimizer+ (the proprietary extension: http://files.zend.com/help/Zend-Server-6/zend-server.htm#zendoptimizerplus.html) but then it sort of changed to adding support for Zend OPcache (the recently open sourced version).
This does only Zend OPcache.
tested on PHP 5.5 and PHP 5.4, including unit tests.
Based on naming scheme, I decided to name the function `hasZendOpcache` (ignoring the abbreviation as with `hasApc`) as opposed to `hasZendOpCache` or other names.
Not sure if this is the 'perfect name' (it gets called in all lower-case in the twig file anyway).

| no
| New feature?

| yes
| BC breaks?

| no
| Deprecations?

| no
| tests pass?

| yes
| fixed tickets |
| License       | MIT
| Doc PR        |
Zend OPCache support would be great.
@Tatsh regarding the name in the other PR, it is because ZO+ has been renamed to Opcache only 2 weeks after being open-sourced, and the PR has been sent in the meantime.
and please create your PR from a feature branch based on the upstream master, not based on a previous PR.
The change for the ``/e`` modifier has nothing to do in this PR and would duplicate the change in the history
Reverted the /e modifier change as I think this might be the cleanest way to go about not having the commit in this PR and not duplicate history should this get merged into 2.1 branch.
@Tatsh no it is not.
You now have 2 unrelated commits in the history.
And it is even worse as merging this PR would now revert the original commit.
The clean way is to use feature branches when sending PRs, so that you do your work based on the upstream state, not based on a previous work.
I will re-do this in a feature branch in a bit.
How do you cancel an ongoing PR?

Sent from my iPhone

On Apr 14, 2013, at 14:52, Christophe Coevoet <notifications@github.com> wrote:

title: suggestion: Css3 mixins should output css3 css also
body: I'm not saying this to support a IE library for css3 just that it would make  compass css3 framework a bit more complete for the future and stop the duck punching.
I agree that the current CSS3 spec format should always be Included when available.
I'll be looking through all the CSS3 mixins this week to update them.

Given the serious difference between the webkit and gecko gradient APIs and the state that they are currently the only browsers which use vendor prefixes to support linear-gradients, it was a fitting solution.
Watching and supporting browsers is far easier than third party browser hacks, and up until recently, they didn't have enough stability to warrant inclusion.
That said, I've been impressed with the potential of CSS3PIE and I'm working on a fork that adds support for it in Compass.
Right now you'll have to use your duck punching though.
The author says it's not ready for primetime and shouldn't be Included in release at this point.
I want to give it a go for a bit and watch his release cycle to see how well it integrates.
Almost all the css3 mixins do output the css standard value.
(M) Gradient might be the only exception to the rule.

For instance: http://compass-style.org/docs/examples/compass/css3/box/#css

I'd be fine with the gradient mixin emitting whatever is the current spec, once it achieves some semblance of stability.
I'm not sure where the process is at for this particular part of the spec.
fixed by f0d80d789fe6979698ca9dd617493e0fff9fed01

title: Extract method refactoring in ActionDispatch::Routing.
body: Another small win.

@Joeybutler thanks for the PR but I'm :-1: on this - @carlosantoniodasilva had pretty much the same commit the other day, though he Included the module rather that calling the method on the module like you've done.
I'm not a big fan of single method modules and there's a deeper reason why this method is duplicated that I'm trying to address with a bigger refactoring of `Mapper`.
(M) Essentially what I'm doing is refactoring the `@scope` instance variable into a class rather than a hash and `Mapping` becomes a subclass of `Scope`.
The `defaults_from_constraints` method would then become a protected instance method and the duplication would be eliminated.
Thanks @Joeybutler, as @pixeltrix commented, I tried a similar approach before and I think @pixeltrix already explained everything :).

title: Integrate Nimbus and DRPC with authentication/authorization framework
body: This pull request integrates Nimbus and DRPC with authentication/authorization framework.

Basically,
  + Nimbus and DRPC are now implemented as ThriftServer and ThriftClient, introduced by auth framework
  + All Nimbus/DRPC methods will perform an authorization check before taking any actions
  + Authorization plugins are configured by 3 new configuration parameters: 
         - nimbus.authorizer for nimbus requests
         - drpc.authorizer for drpc requests
         - drpc.invocations.authorizer for drpc invocation requests
  + nimbus_auth_test.clj and drpc_auth_test.clj are built upon existing test framework and illustrates the expected behavior of NImbus amd DRPC components

Limitation:
  + DRPC server will use the default executor service if SASL transport is used.
This is due to the limitation of Thrift7, and will be removed with Thrift9.

would also be a bonus.

but at first glance I noticed a few style related issues (some of which existed prior to this pull request).

title: Handling a lambda on preserve_files option
body:
Hello, 

Right now preserve_files is handled like a boolean.
I ran into a use case where I needed only certain files to be preserved.
For now, we made this monkey patch so that we can pass a lambda to preserve_files.

```ruby
module Paperclip
  class attachment
    def destroy
      unless preserve_files?

clear
        save
      end
    end
    def queue_all_for_delete
      return if preserve_files?
|| !file?

@queued_for_delete += [:original, *styles.keys].uniq.map do |style|
        path(style) if exists?

(style)
      end.compact

      instance_write(:file_name, nil)
      instance_write(:content_type, nil)
      instance_write(:file_size, nil)
      instance_write(:fingerprint, nil)
      instance_write(:updated_at, nil)
    end

    def preserve_files?

preserve = @options[:preserve_files]
      return preserve.call(instance) if preserve.respond_to?

:call
      preserve
    end
  end
end
```

I was wondering if you were interested in a pull request with that kind of change.
Obviously, I would take more time to ensure that I've covered all the code related to preserve_files.
If you are interested and if you have any hint I should be aware of before I start please let me know.
Thank you
Good idea.
I'd like if this pull request involved a refactoring to extract this common pattern into some abstraction.
@jfabre, if you still want to submit a pull request about this, please do so, but since this is 5 months old, I'm going to close it.
Thanks.

title: aacgain formula version disparity
body: The aacgain formula currently assumes it is downloading source code for aacgain 1.9 when In fact it is actually downloading source code for accgain 1.8.
The formula's current URL, `http://aacgain.altosdesign.com/alvarez/aacgain-1.9.tar.bz2`, actually yields the 1.8 source code insteadof 1.9.

After communicating privately with @davelasker, accgain's developer, this is most likely because the server that's hosting the code is Apache with [mod_speling](http://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.2/mod/mod_speling.html) enabled, so the 1.8 source code gets served when any URL ending in `1.
*.bz2`, including `1.9.bz2`, is requested.

So, the formula should either be changed to explicitly build 1.8, or better yet, should be updated to build 1.9 (although it looks like the [1.9 source code is available in CVS](http://mp3gain.cvs.sourceforge.net/viewvc/mp3gain/aacgain/) rather than as a tarball [where 1.8 is currently served from](http://aacgain.altosdesign.com/alvarez).
Please encourage the author to create a 1.9 tarball.
I believe some discussion around this with the author (@davelasker) has happened here before, search for "aacgain" in the issues/milestones.
If a 1.9 tarball is out of the question, the formula should at least be corrected to point to version 1.8 rather than "faux 1.9".
Looks like this issue has come back as of 6f7ecf4077?

title: highlights internal parts of scala.reflect.runtime
body: By moving them to scala.reflect.runtime.internal.

Noone should be using those classes anyway, because everything except
JavaUniverse is private[XXX] and JavaUniverse itself has the "do not
instantiate" doc comment on it.

On the other hand, our runtime reflection APIs are exposed via
api.JavaUniverse, not via runtime.JavaUniverse, so nothing publicly
accessible refers to the runtime cake.

Finally, reifier is also not using runtime cake directly, preferring
api.JavaUniverse.

It didn't have to, but I feel very relieved that I did
not tap into internal implementation details back then.

here's the code:
https://github.com/scala/scala/blob/v2.10.0/src/compiler/scala/reflect/reify/package.scala#L37
review @retronym @paulp @adriaanm
I like this change.
but we'd stil have to change the MIMA whitelist to exclude `reflect.runtime` to silence it's backward compat warnings.
