title: Handling extension methods in a performant way
body:
https://github.com/joyent/node/issues/6078#issuecomment-23031953

Based on a cursory scan through the current code in http_parser.c one possible approach immediately jumps out at me: handle it similar to the way you handle header field names.
That is, mark the start of the method and run through your method recognition logic.
If you detect one of the methods you know, fantastic, if it's not one that you recognize, set parser->method to some generic "unknown" and do a CALLBACK_DATA(...).
If the callback returns an error, then the method is not recognized... throw your error and move on.
If the callback returns ok, beautiful, move on.
As part of this, add in a check to verify each character is a token and you should be good without any real noticeable impact on performance.
like I said, that's just one approach that stood out given a first pass through the code.

The performance concerns for parsing arbitrary http header names (which are also tokens of unbounded length) are pretty much identical to any concerns you may have about the request method so using a similar approach would seem to make  sense.
see https://github.com/joyent/http-parser/pull/145 for some work towards implementing this.
see pull request #158

title: Using D3 with VML for IE8
body:
Hi

I'm trying to use d3 with VML to support IE8.
I only really need the <v:polyline> tag to display graphs.

This static page works:

```html
<html>
    <head>
        <style>v\:* {behavior:url(#default#VML)}
        </style>
        <script>
            document.namespaces.add('v', 'urn:schemas-microsoft-com:vml', "#default#VML");
        </script>
    </head>
    <body>
        <v:polyline points="10px,20px,50px,50px"></v:polyline>
    </body>
</html>
```

however, when I try to add the polyline dynamically using

```javascript
d3.select('body').append('v:polyline').attr('points', '10px,20px,50px,50px');
```

I think it is because appendElementNS is not supported.

I also tried jQuery with no success:

```javascript
$('body').append($(document.createElement('v:polyline')).attr('points','10px,20px,50px,50px'));
```
Looks like you need to use plain old `document.createElement` for IE6-8 even for namespaced elements.
here is an [example](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb250511%28v%3Dvs.85%29.aspx) (scroll down a bit for some JavaScript).
Not sure why your jQuery equivalent doesn't work though, perhaps the `attr` call isn't compatible.
I see only pain and suffering going down this road.
I think you're better off using server-side rendering or falling back to Raphaël if you want to support IE8-.
@mbostock: You are right.
I no longer could bear the pain and have already switched to using Raphaël

title: add multiple window example
body: Empty
This is super-cool!
@doug confirms.
Does this mean resources can now be shared between contexts so we can finally have multiple renderes using the same assets?
(M) No, it's using one 2D canvas per window and one offscreen WebGL canvas.
(M) It keeps the offscreen canvas as large as the largest width/height for all windows.
(M) Then to render the scene it sets the scissor for a specific window size, renders to the offscreen WebGL canvas, then does ctx2d.drawImage to that window's 2D canvas.
It's slow on Windows but having this sample should put pressure to fix that.
otherwise, when there is a better way to do this we can update.
BTW: I'd like to update this demo so the user can change the scene so that they can see the windows are actually connected.
As it is, you can't tell.
They might as well be separate demos :-p
Simply add [transform controls](https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/blob/dev/examples/misc_controls_transform.html) :)
adding transform controls might not be so easy.
The controls need to handle the multiple views.
As it is each they take a camera but in this case there are N cameras all live at the same time.
It might be possible to switch which camera the controls are tracking based on which window has the focus though I suspect the other views will then end up with strange gizmos

posted a version with transform controls here
https://github.com/greggman/three.js/tree/multiple-windows

Some issues that need fixing:

1.
TransformControls doesn't handle overlapping controls.

If you set the perspective camera down the X axis so all the controls line up, dragging drags all of the,

2.

TransformControls don't work with orthographic cameras AFAICT

I'll play with it a little more before I make  a new pull request.
I dont know if I can do anything about the overlap but I will try to make  the controls work with ortho.
For the time being here's one that doesn't use orthographic views.
Please pull if as is if you think it's ok.
Note it requires this patch (https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/pull/3373)
GIMP users will love this!

title: build: ignore dependencies that are not installed
body: optional dependencies mean that it is possible to install the package without having the dependency installed.
Normally Homebrew installs all dependencies automatically, but `--ignore-dependencies` is an option that disables this behaviour.

but even with `--ignore-dependencies`, build.rb is desperate to have a working /opt prefix for every formula in the dependency tree and raises an exception if it cannot achieve this:

    Error: /usr/local/opt/$dependency not present or broken
    Please reinstall $dependency.

Sorry :(

The attached patch simply prevents build.rb from trying to do anything whatsoever with dependencies that are not actually installed: thus we have no spurious errors, no superfluous components in paths and no unwarranted switching to stdenv.
see also: #14456
That looks awesome!
I believe it does solve this issue too, but how soon will it be merged?
If that’s still a way off, this could be pulled in the meantime.
Ping @jacknagel
I haven't had much uninterrupted time to work on it lately but I still hope to finish and merge it "soonish".
I'll take a closer look at this tomorrow, though.
fixed in 3831d104a727e3ca4d73b06e0851cacda5a7153a - or at least hacked to work again.
That does fix the error, but it also means that dependencies that _are_ installed but haven’t yet got an opt-prefix will be missed.
My solution isn’t much more complicated (even if I change several lines, effectively all changes are the same), so I don’t see why you don’t want to pull it instead.
In fact, if the number of changes is the reason, you can cut it down to a single-line hack by only retaining the change in line 72.
Reopening for review.
@astiob @adamv @jacknagel With the new dependency code I think this is now redundant.
If I'm wrong reopen.
Sorry for not merging and thanks!

title: Pretty up --help formatting
body:
There were several annoying problems with --help formatting:

- Run on text wrapped to left margin insteadof respecting option column indent.

- Left column too long (like --logging) runs into the right column descriptions
- Filenames printed with un-normalized paths (like './myfile.py')

I also add a little vertical white space to set off the differrent file section headings from their contents.
see also: #404

Hoping you'll take either this patch or #404... my change assumes a fixed column width for help formatting (79 cols) - which I think would generally be more readable than long lines on very wide screens; most importantly option defaults are also displayed (which was the main reason I updated this).
Superceded by pull request - https://github.com/facebook/tornado/pull/487

title: fix choppy playback when calling ofSoundPlayer.setPosition (in develop)
body: I'm working on an iOS app that uses ofSoundPlayer.setPosition to jump to different times while playing back a sample.
In OF 0.7.4 it works great with seamless playback while jumping back and forth in one sample.
I'm a little worried as when testing the app against the develop branch of OF the playback is no longer seamless, calling ofSoundPlayer.setPosition becomes noticeably choppy.
(p.s.
GitHub apology, I couldn't work out how to give this issue an iOS label or move it to be "(in develop)", am I missing something?)
no apologies needed, you don't have the permissions to do this.
Hi @edburton, I'll look into this.
The difference between 0.7.4 and 0.8.0 is that we've moved from using the ofxOpenALSoundPlayer to a new sound player (ofxiOSSoundPlayer) which uses AV-found-ation (insteadof OpenAL).
If you need a quick fix, you should be able to get the same behaviour as before by grabbing the ofxOpenALSoundPlayer from 0.7.4.
Can I get some details of your setup?

Stuff like:

* File format that you're using
* Size of the audio file
* Estimate of how long the cut-out is
* How much you're jumping around
* iOS version

EDIT: and if you're using MP3, can you tell me if you still get the same issue with WAV or AAC?

* File format: .caf  (little endian 16 bit, 44,100 sample rate)
* File size: 50 MB
* Cutout: Less than 1/10 second maybe?

* Jumping around: About twice a second
* iOS version: 6.1.4
Alright, I haven't had much time to look into this but it's semi-urgent due to the impending 0.8.0 and the fact that it's a pretty legitimate regression.
@julapy?
I'm not sure how much can be done, since the AVAudioPlayer API is pretty fire-and-forget.
I don't think there's many places to force the player to optimize for things like instant seeking.
As far as I know, the only real "optimization" work that can be done in AVAudioPlayer is just scheduling future playback to happen at an exact moment, which doesn't cover this use case.
Might be worth investigating if WAVs and AACs have this issue.
@edburton also might be worth trying an mp3 or m4a - weirdly the AVAudioPlayer can be fast/faster with those formats.
the OpenAL based player loaded the whole sound into memory ( uncompressed ), so that could explain the fast seek times.
@admsyn do you think there is a way we can add an option to decode the sound buffer into memory?
Not with AV-found-ation, as far as I know.

IIRC the design of many AV-found-ation bits intentionally tries to separate you from the raw stuff like buffers and decoding so it can intelligently make  use of onboard decoder chips and such (grain of salt).
The AV-found-ation player has many improvements over the old one, but this is a specific use case where the old system really did work best.
I'm not really sure what'd be the best way to handle this, since this really is like a 1% use case, where we want to do sampler / MPC style instant seeking (I assume?).
FWIW I think dipping down to the Audio Unit level is the way to handle the tight playback control you'd need to pull this off.
The iOS OpenAL implementation kind of hung out in this nether region that was basically a thin wrapper over  straight Audio Unit / Core Audio stuff.
.. *thinks* ..
I have an implementation of an oF-friendly wrapper over the AUFilePlayer (an audio unit that's available on OSX and iOS).

This is geared towards OSX and the ofxAudioUnit "architechture", but it might be something we could tweak for iOS super-fast to get it ready for 0.8.0 in the case that: A) We don't find a workaround, B) this regression is unacceptable and C) bringing back the ofxOpenALSoundPlayer would involve too much pain :)

https://github.com/admsyn/ofxAudioUnit/blob/master/src/ofxAudioUnitFilePlayer.cpp

EDIT: just to clarify, I'm saying this could be provided as a secondary / fallback sound player in the case where you want to do things like @edburton
I've just tried WAV and AAC, no change.
Do you think it'd work if I have two ofSoundPlayer's and faded from one to the other?
I should be able to work out in advance where I need the next playhead jump to be, so there might be some sort of work-around where I call setPosition a few moments before play.
Trouble is I need to know that the timing is going to be precise enough to keep percussion in sync as I jump/fade from one beat to another.
I must admit; I did think I was a surprisingly lucky 1% when the old version worked so seamlessly.
We could try calling `prepareToPlay` in the init process.
I don't think it'll have much effect outside of the initial "play" call, but it's worth a shot.

@admsyn when I try that I get a warning...

```
"/users/ed/documents/openFrameworksGithub/addons/ofxiOS/src/sound/ofxiOSSoundPlayer.mm:26:6: 'AVSoundPlayer' may not respond to 'prepareToPlay'"
```
...and when running it throws...

```
2013-07-25 17:56:17.259 Tunetrace[2098:907] -[AVSoundPlayer prepareToPlay]: unrecognized selector sent to instance 0x1962fc0
2013-07-25 17:56:17.263 Tunetrace[2098:907] *** Terminating app due to uncaught exception 'NSInvalidArgumentException', reason: '-[AVSoundPlayer prepareToPlay]: unrecognized selector sent to instance 0x1962fc0'
```
Ah, I was looking at the wrong abstraction layer :) `prepareToPlay` is already being called in the AVSoundPlayer.
@edburton RE: your previous comment about keeping two sound players.
That would work, because the underlying AVAudioPlayer has an affordance for scheduling future playback quite reliably.
(M) I don't think that's exposed in the ofxiOSSoundPlayer wrapper, though.
would that work for your app?
(M) soundPlayer.playAtTime(whenToPlay) might do very nicely.
Is there any chance it could come with a matching soundPlayer.stopAtTime(whenToStop) perhaps?

@admsyn @edburton,
think you can load a sound, pause it, jump to position, and play when you are ready.
thats what you're describing above right?
@edburton, think the easiest solution in your case would be to jump back to using ofxOpenALSoundPlayer.
the API should be exactly the same as they both extend ofBaseSoundPlayer.
@admsyn I think I probably am too eccentric an edge case to be drifting from the ofBaseSoundPlayer API when you're all so close to 0.8.
I promise not to sulk when 0.8 comes out if my lazy jumps become slightly choppy.
@julapy yep, pause, jump, play, repeat, with two playheads, is what I had in mind.
It would have the advantage that I'd be able to do a slight fade rather than a cut.
I am in a hurry to deliver a commercial project though so if I can stick with ofxOpenALSoundPlayer I might do that.
Two remaining questions then.
A) Do people expect ofxOpenALSoundPlayer to carry on working with iOS7?
B) What would be the tidiest way to use ofxOpenALSoundPlayer while still being able to pull from the develop branch as 0.8 approaches?
> What would be the tidiest way to use ofxOpenALSoundPlayer while still being able to pull from the develop branch as 0.8 approaches?
hm, [cs]hould we farm it out into a mini-addon, for those 1% cases?
@edburton - best is to just copy the old files into a new folder in the addons folder.

then add those files to your app project and just use #Include "ofxOpenALSoundPlayer.h"

The reason we removed it, is it is really buggy in terms of deallocation ( lots of crashes on exit issues ) and the c based code is quite a nightmare to work with.
I would be interested in getting better seektime performance for the new sound player though.

some relevant SO pages: 
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2699093/avaudioplayer-seek-performance-is-not-good
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/882753/avaudioplayer-currenttime-problem

Oh my, I would be a very appreciative 1% if that were possible @bilderbuchi , as well as my own http://tunetrace.com it'll be a couple of large brands so it'll be helpful towards overall plan of OpenFrameworks global domination :-)

ah, thanks @ofTheo, that is really useful.
I've been noticing those crashes on exit and am somewhat relived to be able to blame ofxOpenALSoundPlayer rather than my probably even more suspect OpenCV hacks :-)
One thing I'm currently wondering: Is the AVAudioPlayer doing a quick fade out / in every time the audio changes positions to avoid clicks and pops?
It sounds very "smooth" to me whenever the audio jumps around, where I'd expect there to be a bit of pop if it were actually cutting out then starting up again.
FWIW I've seen people run into issues like this with AVAssetreader, where it was ramping up the first ~30 ms of any audio that was read in (grain of salt, again).
If so, that'd be some :shit:

So here's what the seeking looks like:
!

[waveform](http://i.imgur.com/bU9BtQK.png)

It looks like there's a bit of a fade in / out being applied, but it's also taking a while to buffer up the sound.
I'm *pretty* sure this isn't solvable with the AVAudioPlayer-backed sound player.

closed by #2363 

@edburton @admsyn added the OpenALSoundPlayer back into the iOS project - so you should be able to use that insteadof ofSoundPlayer

title: Trouble Getting Jekyll to have maruku perform tex -> png
body: I am able to have maruku convert tex to png when I invoke it directly, however, it will not work when going through jekyll.

My _config.yml is being discovered as reported by jekyll and contains the appropriate settings:
```
maruku:
  use_tex:    true
  use_divs:   true
  png_engine: blahtex
  png_dir:    images/latex
  png_url:    /images/latex
```
Is there something I'm missing?
This does not seem to be a common application so I had a very difficult time finding any information on the issue.
Any recommendations and help is greatly appreciated.
Paths should end in slashes.

(M) ```yaml
maruku:
  use_tex:    true
  use_divs:   true
  png_engine: blahtex
  png_dir:    images/latex/
  png_url:    /images/latex/
```

If you have .png files with size zero, modify "/maruku/ext/math/mathml_engines/blahtex.rb:19" from

```ruby
if not File.exists?

(result_file)
```

to

```ruby
if not File.size?

(result_file)
```

Maybe I'll fix these today, if they aren't fixed already.
Or maybe I did something wrong - I'm new to Jekyll - but this fixed my problems.
There where no images generated and none of the tex had been interpreted when I appended the slashes.
I tried the second fix anyway, but it didn't fix anything.
My config is copied straight from the wiki so I feel confident there is nothing wrong there.
So maruku does not process .textile files unless you throw one at it directly through the CLI.
Changing to a .md resolved all my problems.

title: webgl renderer has gotten very slow?
body: As I've been working on thingiview.js https://github.com/tbuser/thingiview.js (uses three.js, but parses STL and OBJ files directly in javascript without having to preprocess the files) I've noticed that the webgl renderer has gotten a lot slower than it used to be.
I'm not sure which update or what has caused it?
The canvas renderer seems to have gotten much faster and now seems to be even faster than webgl in most cases.
Is that with the master branch or the materials branch?
(We started a materials branch recently because we had some refactoring to do with materials)
I've only been using the master branch.

I think I tracked it down to this commit that added multiple light support to webgl: https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/commit/1c35d90fd7198deb7278492b3989e3f7a8e817f2 Even if I comment out all the lights, it still crawls for me.
The commit right before that is super fast.
Didn't notice any slow downs on my setup.
What graphics card do you have?
Have you tried on another machine?
I just tried it on my iMac at work, same significant slow down.

(M) For instance the example at: http://mrdoob.github.com/three.js/examples/geometry_large_mesh.html gives:

canvas ~30 fps
webgl ~1 fps

OS X 10.6.4
2.8 GHz Core 2 Duo
4 GB ram
ATI Radeon HD 2600 Pro
Chrome 9.0.572.1 dev
I just tried Minefield 4.0b8pre and it is getting the same bad performance on webgl.
That's impossible... Maybe you're getting confused with the color of the selected option.
Yellow means selected (I've seen other people get confused with this too, I'll fix).
I can't believe that the canvas renderer is rendering 100k polys at 30fps ;)
haha I think you're right, sorry.

I can't get that example to be more than 1 fps here at home using either webgl or canvas, so I setup my own test as an example:

OS X 10.6.4
2 GHz core duo
2 GB ram
ATI Radeon X1600

Minefield 4.0b8pre

http://replimat.com/thingiview/examples/
old three.js webgl - 100 fps

http://replimat.com/new_thingiview/examples/
new three.js webgl - 30 fps

The only difference between those 2 urls is the version of three.js.
Oh and using regular Chrome at either url using canvas - 60fps, twice as fast as Minefield using webgl on the new version.

What's weird is that none of them work in Chrome here :/

however:

Ubuntu 10.10
2.53 GHz Core 2 Duo
4 GB ram
Nvidia GeForce 9400M 

Firefox 4.0beta7

Both of them run at 100fps, until I interact, then it goes down to 60fps.
I'll ping alteredq, to see if he knows what's going on.
Yeah, I'm not sure why Chrome stopped working with webgl in either version, it works with canvas and used to work with webgl.
I'm not sure if it's a bugor something I'm doing yet, but I think it started failing after I added my own web worker loader.

So, I tried it on my setup:

    Windows 7 64bit
    2.4 GHz Core2 Duo
    4 GB RAM
    ATI Mobility Radeon 3650

And it runs like this:

Both old and new version do not show anything in Chrome (latest dev channel 9.0.576.0 and canary 9.0.583.0).
In Firefox 4 beta 7 they both run at more or less the same speed, e.g WaltHead low poly is about 110-120 FPS when autorotating and ~63FPS after interaction.

Given your description of when this slowdown started to appear and your system specifications I suspect what what could be going on:

A) for your particular system configuration (GPU + OS) new shader got too complex and it somehow started to trigger software rendering (on the level below WebGLRenderer like browser/OS/GPU driver).
Though this is unlikely, you probably wouldn't be getting even 30 fps with SW rendering (unless the numbers you mention are for some simple scene, like default cube.
For which object are your 30/60fps numbers in WebGL/Canvas?)
Also I know nothing about OSX rendering backend, can it use SW rendering for OpenGL?
I think at some point in WebGL history some browsers used Mesa SW renderer as fallback, that's why I thought this could be going on.
B) new version of shader rubs your GPU driver in some bad way which results in slowdown.
Did you try to update your GPU drivers?

I used to have horrible problems on my system when I used old drivers (latest one given officially by notebook manufacturer Lenovo, while the latest one from GPU manufacturer ATI have been working flawlessly).
Welcome to the hell of HW acceleration on multiple OSs / GPUs :S
One more thing I realized when going through my multi-lights commit which triggered this slowdown: how did you comment out the lights?
Were the for loops in shaders still in place?
This is somehow contentious area as for multilights I use uniforms as loop boundaries.
This is supposed to be supported in GPUs only since some time (which was already pretty long ago, but both your GPUs are pretty old).

I may anyways have to change the implementation as it seems this feature will eventually be prevented at shader validation phase:

http://code.google.com/p/angleproject/issues/detail?id=48

After doing more testing on multiple other machines (both Macs and PCs), it seems as though the only one having this problem is my old MacBookPro with an ATI Radeon HD 2600 Pro (which unfortunately happens to be what I do most of my development on at home).
So far as I know, the only way to get Mac video drivers is through Software update, which means I have the latest drivers.
I had commented out the code that added lights to the scene thinking the multiple lights I had was causing the problem, I didn't change anything in three.js itself.
So I'm guessing this is just an issue with that particular GPU.
Thanks for the report and tests.
With so many possible combinations of HW and SW you never know what effects you will get.
I'll eventually refactor WebGLRenderer to use only fixed size loops for multiple lights, but it may take a while and it will probably go just in materials branch.
If you commented out lights in the scene, shader will be compiled to handle default of 1 directional + 4 point lights (which will be empty, but code may be executed anyways).
It may be better to use e.g.
just one directional light insteadof zero lights.
About drivers: ATI historically used to have worse OpenGL drivers than NVidia (while for DirectX situation was reversed).
You had to pay extra for FireGL versions of their cards to get decent OpenGL performance.

I don't know how is situation for Macs, but for Windows notebooks, there is usually huge delay between officially sanctioned drivers by notebook manufacturers and drivers by GPU creators (in my case it's more than 1 year and difference was big - many things were broken or crashing with obsolete drivers).

title: Alternative proposal for filter API
body:
This is an alternative proposal to PR #1683 

like that PR, this adds a public API for filters in `Include/git2/filter.h` and a plug-in API for filters in `Include/git2/sys/filter.h`.
The API here is somewhat different than what is proposed in that PR, although not too different in the end.

In additionto updating the default internal way of finding and applying filters, this adds a simple new public API to get the content of a blob in filtered form `git_blob_filtered_content` and a very granular API for applying filters to data (via `git_filter_list_load` and the various forms of `git_filter_list_apply_...`).
As part of these new public APIs, I felt like it was time to create a public `git_buffer` object that could be used for passing data into and out of filters and other related calls.
Writing this code with a public `git_buffer` is awkward.
As a test of the filter writing APIs, this adds the "ident" filter to libgit2.
It wasn't too hard to write, which make s me feel like the API is not too bad.

Because the filter registry is a global list which needs to be cleaned up at shutdown time and because this is now the third or fourth global shutdown routine, I added a very simply list of global shutdown callbacks to `src/global.c` and converted all of the various shutdown routines to use that.
It is terribly dumb, but I think it will be fine for now.

- [x] Write enough for an interesting discussion
- [ ] Moar tests
This is not done, but any means.

actually, I apologize that I wrote this much code before opening up the PR, but given the existing PR #1683, I felt like I had to take this far enough along so that there would be something to actually discuss.
The early commits are somewhat similar to what's implemented in #1683 and I wanted to move further along towards the API that I was trying for.

At this point, I'd mostly like feedback on a few things:

1.
This finally adds a public `git_buffer` object.

That is somewhat different that the internal `git_buf` because I wanted to have the notion of an unwritable buffer (where the memory was not owned by libgit2) vs a writable buffer (where libgit2 does own the memory).
I think it came out okay, but I suspect my design choices will be controversial.
I'm open to suggestions.

I hope the main initial focus will be on `Include/git2/filter.h` which contains the proposal for the public filter API that would be used by people not writing filters but wants to apply filter chains to their own data insteadof relying on libgit2 to internally apply the filters.
The other main area that needs feedback is `Include/git2/sys/filter.h` which Includes the plugin filter API.
I'm proposing a global filter registry, not a per-repository one, and I've got a number of functions to manage the entire filter lifecycle.
It is a lot, I'm afraid, but I didn't see a great way around it.

Part of the plug in filter API that I'm most happy with is the idea that a filter can simply give a list of attributes that it cares about and the filter framework will automatically look them up and even check values for them.
My goal was to make  it very easy and natural to base filter application on attribute settings so that plugin authors would prefer that.
There are a variety of other things to comment on and this needs a ton more tests before it will be ready.
Also, I'm conscious that this is more code than #1683 so maybe once the discussion gets going, we will decide that going with a smaller approach is a better first step.
Discussing that is totally on the table.

Anyhow, I will continue to work on more tests for this, etc., and hope that some other folks will have time to start looking over the public-facing pieces of this (and the internals, too, given time and interest).
*yawn* just went through all of it.
That was a lot of code to read.

;)

Basically, as far as I'm concerned this is the way to go.
The APIs look like what we need, the code looks clean.
(M) Exporting a buffer is the way to go.
(M) The double-buffering when applying filters is :mansecks:.

Two painpoints:

- I can't cope with `git_buffer` and `git_buf` having the exact same signature and being different structs.
I think that unifying this into `git_buf` and exporting that would make  this perfect.
We don't need to export the full `git_buf` API, just the minimal amount for clients to interact with it.
- The shutdown stuff looks slightly overengineered.
It doesn't need to be atomic, for starters, and I'm not sure if registering shutdown callbacks is the best idea, when we could just explicitly call the shutdown functions.

So yeah, let's see how hard is it to unify the two buffers, and wrap this up with as many tests as you think they are necessary, but as far as I'm concerned this supersedes the other filter proposals.
I'd also like to see how @ethomson likes this (or how mad he is about it), because I think he was already using some kind of filtering, so hopefully this doesn't screw him up *too much*.
Indeed, I will try to give this a read through but I regret that I may not be able to get to it until the weekend.
(Sorry!
Still getting caught up with the day job after all my moving craziness!)
@yorah may also have some feedback, hopefully he can also take a peek!
@vmg Unifying the two buffer implementations make s sense.
I was hesitant because of some of the conventions that we follow with the internal one, but now that you've said it, I'm already thinking about ways to manage that.
I'm looking forward to trying it out, now.
@ethomson @yorah Definitely both of your feedback will be appreciated if you can make  time.
I'm sorry this was so long in coming, but I spent a lot of time thinking about they work that you two had done and what I would like to see it become.

I still have several days of work to address the @vmg comments and to fill out the test suite, so there is no big rush for you to review (and it may make  sense to wait, at least until I unify the buffer object implementations which will probably simplify things a bit).
Also, if you don't mind, I may try to cherry pick some tests from #1683 and adapt them for the API differences.
Okay, so I coalesced `git_buffer` into `git_buf` which was a nice reduction in code size.
Still more tweaks and tests to go.
By the way, there will be a secondary effect if this PR gets merged which is that all those APIs where we said "if only `git_buf` were public, this would be cleaner" we could now go and fix.
That is not work for this PR, but we can address it with a follow up as needed...
The main thing left that I want to tackle is making sure that `ident` and `crlf` filters are applied in the right priority order when used together and that our behavior matches core Git for them.
I'll need to write tests that try add-to-index, checkout, and diff all with files where both ident and crlf are active.
I'm trying to think of a case where out-of-order application would possibly make  a different for these two filters though, and I'm having trouble thinking of one.
I may have to use a custom filter to ensure that the ordering is actually correct.
I imported a couple of test helper functions that I wrote a while ago when initially playing with filtering.
One is an easy way to test file content and one is an easy way to create a commit on the fly.
Both of these are actually net reductions in lines of test code because they centralize testing patterns that were already in use.
I also wrote a new test that applies both crlf and ident filtering to blobs together.
I couldn't come up with a case with just those two filters where order mattered, but I stepped through and observed that I had things in the wrong order and fixed it.

I still plan on writing some more tests - the existing ident + crlf test can be extended with a few more test cases and I would like to add a custom filter into the mix, too, so that I really prove the filter ordering with a test that would fail if I had it wrong.
Getting closer, though!
Ha ha.
Eyeballing the diff, I think about 50% of this PR is either comments in the public headers or test code.
I guess that's not so bad.
Anyone think `git_filter_list` should be renamed to either `git_filters` (which seems to easily confusable with `git_filter`) or `git_filter_chain`?
Given that we have a `git_diff_list` and `git_status_list`, I'm inclined to leave it, but something about `git_filter_chain` is appealing.
I think `list` is reasonable.
Also, those 50% comments are awesome.

:)

I've noticed that the filter structs callback APIs are typedefed, commented, and then used inside the struct... We don't usually do this, but the extra typedeffing gives extra comment space which looks great.
Maybe we should unify the other callback structs.

added some more tests, including some that mix the ident filter with what would be equivalent to a "filter=xyz" custom filter driver in core Git so that I could prove to myself that the order of execution was now correct.
I also made it so that the ident filter will refuse to run on file content that appears to be binary.
I'm not sure if this is the correct behavior or not.
Is it possible that someone would have a binary file and still want an embedded string with `$Id$` to be expanded to the SHA of the file in Git?
I guess I should probably just read the core Git code to see what they do there.
For now, I've made it so that the libgit2 ident filter will skip files that appear to be binary data (just as the CRLF filter does).
Hmm, the failing tests on Windows are interesting.

The custom filter tests that I grabbed from the original filters PR are written for the filters to run after CRLF filtering on checkin, but a normal Git custom filter driver runs before CRLF filtering.
When I added new tests that verify that libgit2 filter order matches core Git, I broke this test on Windows because I moved the custom filter to the same place in the filter order as core Git.
Unfortunately, my new test depends on the filter running *before* the internal filters because I need its actions to prevent the ident filter from running.
I think I just need to move the priority of the custom filters back to running pre-CRLF and then make  a new custom filter for my test.
> Is it possible that someone would have a binary file and still want an embedded string with $Id$ to be expanded to the SHA of the file in Git?
Ew, no.
That'd open a whole can of worms which we probably shouldn't mess with.
Pending feedback from @ethomson and/or @yorah I don't have anything else I plan to add to this PR at this point.
I mainly looked at the `.h` files, and this looks pretty good!
This definitely fits the needs of the initial PR, and the code is clean and easy to read.

I will play with the C# bindings as soon as it gets merged, so that `Archive` can finally be implemented in LibGit2Sharp :smile:

:clap: :star2:
Lovely.
Thank you @arrbee!
I'll merge as soon as I can verify that @ethomson didn't get a stroke from this PR.
It was only a minor stroke.
This looks very nice to me, I think.
I'm glad to have a public `git_buf` now, I hope that this will solve a lot of problems.
Thanks for attacking this @arrbee.
Brilliant.
It looks like my overly aggressive merging of PRs has caused this to fall behind.
We'll ship as soon as @arrbee rebases.
Bonus imaginary points for the first person to open a PR porting some of sucky external APIs to use the new `git_buf`.
What a great success.

title: `brew linkapps` fails wrt custom formulae
body: make  a custom formula "foo.rb" that does `prefix.install "foo.app"`.
`cd` to the dir containing said formula and brew it with `brew install -d ./foo`.
Observe that it builds and that foo.app is in `/usr/local/cellar/foo/1.0/` (or whatever the version num is).
Do `brew linkapps --system`.
Observe that foo.app is not linked into `/applications`.
BTW it make s no difference whether the `--system` flag is passed; foo.app won't get linked into `~/applications` either.
I think that linkapps ought to handle custom local formula.
It's true that if one moves `foo.rb` into `/usr/local/library/formula` it works OK, but I don't want to have to move it in there and deal with merging and associated crap.
Especially if I'm just testing out foo.
`brew linkapps` shouldn't care whether `foo.rb` is part of the official repo of formulae.
The reason it matters is that if there is more than one keg, e.g.
foo/0.1 and foo/0.2, it doesn't know which one to -CHOOSE-.
(Not saying it can't be improved, just pointing out why it does this currently)
(M) Maybe: https://github.com/jacknagel/homebrew/compare/linkapps
worked fine over here on an initial test.
Thanks!

title: libboost_regexp misses Unicode ICU support
body:
Hello,

It seems that lobboost_regexp misses Unicode ICU support.
It would be great if that could be added.

Thank you,
ambs
@jacknagel @Sharpie @mistydemeo @mikemcquaid This comes up from time to time; I think MacPorts build boost against icu.
We closed it last time; what about now?
I think we try and minimise dependencies where Macports doesn't.
add as an option?
Not easy to do, but you could divide libboost in boost-headers (the part that doesn't need C build), and a boost-regexp/boost-filesystem/boost-* for each of the other boost libraries.
And, who knows, a libboost that installs all these.
but as I said, not easy to do.
And I do not have knowledge to help with that.
Cheers
We could add a `--with-unicode-icu` build option for boost, if it's not common enough to warrant being the default.
It would probably be easier not to split it up.
Happy with it :)
If we do this, it has to be an option otherwise the bottle gets messy.
Anyone care to submit a patch for this?
@ambs?
I am getting some trouble to build it myself by hand.
Already submitted some bugreports to boost guys.
Will give news as I have them.
Anybody can point me to a formula with options so I can try to learn how to do it?

:)

Thank you
(yep, managed to build it!)
just search for "def options" in existing formula
thanks.
Sorry for using this as discussion :) is there any canonical way to find the path for another installed formula?

@ambs `Formula.factory('foo').prefix`

The Formula instance variables are the same ones you can use when writing a formula.
testing my patch.
Meanwhile, anybody knows why these formula libraries get a suffix -mt ?
When I build the library manually I don't get them.
@ambs We build boost in multithread mode, which is what `-mt` represents.
You were probably compiling it without `threading=multi` when doing it manually.

Oh, thanks @mistydemeo 

Meanwhile, https://github.com/mxcl/homebrew/pull/10031 has a pull request that support --with-icu, but I need to clean up that branch.
My git-fu is not great, so, will try after dinner.

2.

3.

News title of post

Link: something.com

title: Prevent creation of database columns with a reserved name
body:
Today I ran into [this issue](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4726820/rails-activerecord-update-attributes-problems): apparently a database column with the name `hash` breaks things, resulting in a non-helpful error: 

```
TypeError (can't convert String into Integer)
```

Creation of columns with reserved names should be prevented.
If that is impossible, a more helpful error message would be awesome.
Any other words except `hash`?

title: [SecurityBundle] moved all non-class parameters to the Configuration file
body: [SecurityBundle] moved all non-class parameters to the Configuration file
My understanding of our decision was that the parameters should be completely removed.
here, you have just moved the definition of the parameter to the extension class.
In all other bundles, we inject the value directly with `setArgument()`.

here is an example:

https://github.com/symfony/symfony/commit/c8fe15bfcf2053a4666af1d4cdd559f2808a9997
Ok, I've inlined all the parameters that were only used in one place.
If the parameter was used by more than one service, I have kept it.
Is `security.access.always_authenticate_before_granting` used more than once?
Well, not yet :) but it will be used in the SecurityExtraBundle.
Err, so you want to integrate these two bundles by reading the SecurityBundle parameters?
I guess its a special case, but in general we didnt encourage this.
Imho in that case SecurityExtraBundle should set SecurityBundle as its parent.
The parameters defined in a bundle are not visible in any other bundle.
At least, that used to work like this, and I want to keep this behavior.
Each bundle should be isolated from the others.
@fabpot they are not available in the extension but they can be used as argument of a service (and it always worked this way).
So as long as the extension does not need to resolve the value (which should be avoided anyway) there is no issue about using it.

title: brew info does not * linked installations if there is only one installed version
body:
josiah-kiehl:Formula jkiehl$ brew unlink znc
    josiah-kiehl:Formula jkiehl$ brew info znc
    znc 0.204
    http://wiki.znc.in/ZNC
    Depends on: pkg-config, c-ares
    /usr/local/Cellar/znc/0.204 (151 files, 5.0M)
    https://github.com/mxcl/homebrew/commits/master/Library/Formula/znc.rb
    josiah-kiehl:Formula jkiehl$ brew link znc
    Linking /usr/local/Cellar/znc/0.204... 10 symlinks created
    josiah-kiehl:Formula jkiehl$ brew info znc
    znc 0.204
    http://wiki.znc.in/ZNC
    Depends on: pkg-config, c-ares
    /usr/local/Cellar/znc/0.204 (151 files, 5.0M)
    https://github.com/mxcl/homebrew/commits/master/Library/Formula/znc.rb

I'm trying to add version support to the chef provider for homebrew but I can't find any way to tell if a given package is linked if there is only one version installed.
I'd prefer that the * present when 2 or more versions are installed would be present at all times when a version is linked.

eg:

when linked:

    /usr/local/Cellar/znc/0.204 (151 files, 5.0M) *


when not linked:

    /usr/local/Cellar/znc/0.204 (151 files, 5.0M)

It probably make  sense to always show the asterisk if something is linked, but if you want to programmatically determine this, it is going to be more robust to look at the symlinks in Library/LinkedKegs, rather than parsing the output of `brew info`, which is subject to change and should not be considered a scriptable interface.
fixed in c7d9a09
Fair point about looking for symlinks.
I'll take that approach instead.
Nonetheless thanks for the patch.
:D

title: Non-dirty serialized columns are being saved anyway
body:
New Rails 3.2.9 app with one model that has a serialized column:

```ruby
rails new ar_serialized_dirty_test
cd ar_serialized_dirty_test

rails g model Product name:string data:text
rake db:migrate

# product.rb

class Product < ActiveRecord::Base
  serialize :data
end
```

On every save, this column is being updated, regardless if it was changed or not.

```ruby
> p = Product.create(name: "A")
  SQL (0.6ms)  INSERT INTO "products" ("created_at", "data", "name", "updated_at") VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?)

[["created_at", Mon, 26 Nov 2012 23:08:26 UTC +00:00], ["data", nil], ["name", "A"], ["updated_at", Mon, 26 Nov 2012 23:08:26 UTC +00:00]]
 => #<Product id: 1, name: "A", data: nil, created_at: "2012-11-26 23:08:26", updated_at: "2012-11-26 23:08:26"> 
> p.save!
(0.3ms)  update "products" SET "updated_at" = '2012-11-26 23:08:34.660484', "data" = '---\n...\n' Where "products".

"id" = 1
 => true 
> p.save!
(0.3ms)  update "products" SET "updated_at" = '2012-11-26 23:08:45.777419', "data" = '---\n...\n' Where "products".

"id" = 1
 => true 
> p.data_changed?

=> false 
> p.save!
(0.3ms)  update "products" SET "updated_at" = '2012-11-26 23:13:20.839794', "data" = '---\n...\n' Where "products".
+1 for that
This is the intended behavior.
It was added with this commit 144e8691cbfb8bba77f18cfe68d5e7fd48887f5e by @jonleighton .

There is even an explantation why it behaves the way it does:

```ruby
# Serialized attributes should always be written in case they've been
# changed in place.

def keys_for_partial_write
  changed | (attributes.keys & self.class.serialized_attributes.keys)
end
```

The problem is that serialized data-structures can be changed without using the ActiveRecord setters.
Then there is no way to detect that a change actually happend.
To work around this problem serialized attributes are written all the time.
@senny right.
Closing it.
@elado thank you for reporting.
Thanks.

Indeed, looks like `_changed?` method doesn't return true if I change a value within a value, `p.data[:x] = 1`

What about keeping the original serialized value after fetching and compare it to the current serialized value before saving?
@elado I think this is a unnecessary overhead, much more than writing the serialized attribute every time.
@rafaelfranca think large scale, 1M+ writes per minute to the RDB.
on the ruby side, that wouldn't take too much time, but it can bring a really strong SQL machine down on its knees.

there are less expensive ways of doing this than comparing, for instance, extend the serialized object to have a changed attribute accessor and when a setter method is called on it, it will also set that value to true.
@rafaelfranca, as @unorthodoxgeek said, it's definitely a performance issue.

insteadof an expensive DB access for no reason, Rails could either serialize the initial value after fetching and compare to it to the current serialized value for dirty check, or have `#eql?` method in the serializer class (the one that has `#load`/`#dump`) that'll compare things by content.
I believe usually the serialized attribute is a Hash or an Array, so `#eql?` shouldn't be that expensive.

Let's remember this code overhead (not performance overhead) only happens when there are serialized attributes, and current state is that a query is executed every time and this is far longer operation.
Thanks
@elado If you can come up with a good PR I think there is nothing that will prevent it from getting merged.
As the current behavior is known and expected we don't treat this as a bugthough.
Feel free to use the [Rails Core](https://groups.google.com/forum/?fromgroups#!forum/rubyonrails-core) GoogleGroup to discuss the idea and the change you want to make .
Of course you can also just hack up the PR and start a discussion with it.
@elado @unorthodoxgeek I see.
It make  sense.
Mind to open a pull request?
I'm reopening this issue.
@tenderlove has talked to me about using `Object#hash` to determine which attributes have changed.
That seems like to way to go to me.
Then we don't need special handling for serialized attributes.
The challenge here is how to "save the original" for comparison purposes - just stashing it someplace isn't sufficient.
In particular, users may wind up with *silent* data loss...
(M) what about marshalling it and saving an md5 of the output string?

should be
a fairly good way of comparing two hard-to-compare objects...
This isn't the ideal solution, but why not note when the serialized attribute is read/written to and only save it in that case.
If the attribute hasn't been read it couldn't have been modified.

For applications where the serialized attribute is rarely accessed this would cut down on extraneous SQL calls while avoiding some of complexities in the proposals that try to compare versions of the serialized attribute.
I agree with @elado's initial suggestion of storing the original unserialized string, but maybe as a MD5 hash.

If you have:

```
class Product < ActiveRecord::Base
  serialize :categories, Array
end
```

then the original string's MD5 hash could be stored somewhere like `@product.unserialized_categories_hash` or `@product.unserialized_attribute_hashes['categories']`, before being parsed.
That would make  it easy to detect changes properly, even if the attribute is modified in place.

+1

@tenderlove via @jonleighton had the answer.
Every object has a .hash method.
Call that to see if the serialized hash is different.
If so, mark as dirty.
@jonleighton any thoughts on how to retrieve old value so that when ` p.data_changed?` is invoked we can do the `Object#hash` matching.
Looking at the code I could not find any clean way to retrieve the old value when the  value is changed in-memory.
So how do we handle the following scenario?
I modify some data on a serialized data.
(say, i delete some values in the data array).
I would want to save the data only if its changed.
Why should i unnecessarily update a row if there is no value changed.
(i m on a loop and only some data will be changed based on condition)
Is there a way to disable this at a per-model level ?
@senny Referring back to your code quote from @jonleighton, I'm not sure why serialized data is so special just because it can be changed in-place.
A string can also be changed in place without the changes being detected.

```ruby
user = user.first
user.first_name.replace('changed')
user.first_name #=> "changed"
user.changes #=> {}
```
users who are modifying serialized data in-place are not, since that data is always saved.
supporting in-place changes feels like it is beyond the scope of this discussion, no?
Not least because trying to support it (and being consistent) would require that a shadow `.clone` always be held for every attribute, serializable or not.
There's a clear cost associated with that.
Or the ambiguity that is created around saying 'you can modify some attributes in place but not others' if you only support it for serializable attributes - a recipe for more bugs perhaps?
As @jonleighton pointed out, using the `.hash` 'interface' at least gives a clean, standardised way for comparing equality when it comes to setting an attribute.
It would also push the task of `.clone` (or similar) onto the caller, but this seems like a fair compromise if speed/efficiency is the goal.
So +1 for the use of `.hash` in determining whether an attribute has changed when it is set via `=` etc.
This would then allow accurate tracking of whether the attribute is dirty or not and therefore short-circuiting of database writes if the attribute hasn't changed.

A nd then another +1 for spelling out in the docs that in-place changes won't be picked up (particularly [here](http://api.rubyonrails.org/classes/ActiveRecord/Base.html)) - I got bitten by this because I (wrongly?)
wrapped my `obj.save` with `if obj.changed?`
@myitcv If the .hash implementation is used, there will be no need to document gotchas with in-place changes since they would be detected.
@njakobsen - true, but I think the only way to 'detect' _all_ in-place updates would be to store a hash for _every_ attribute at the persistence layer.
Loading from the DB would trigger a hash calculation on each attribute for the pre value, then persisting would need to compute a hash value for each attribute....
seems like a big overhead (in terms of processing and memory), no?
(I realise this retreats slightly on my earlier comment about needing to keep a shadow `.clone` - a hash would suffice)
@myitcv Yes it probably would, though I imagine it would be worth looking into as most attributes would have simple integer or string values anyway.
however, I think the overhead of *always* saving a record simply because it has a serialized column is what is really the issue here.
My previous comment (probably unnecessary) was not to suggest a course of action, just to point out that the documentation was unnecessary if all columns used the hash method of dirty checking.
+1 for hash checking of serialized attributes because it would definitely be faster than serializing them and saving them just in case they change.
I just hit this issue myself.
One thing I was wishing for was a way to mark a serialized attribute as unchanged (e.g.
`#some_attribute_will_not_change!`).
In my use case it would be pretty easy for me to compare the attribute value myself and mark it unchanged when appropriate.
This isn't an ideal solution, but might be a reasonable extension of the current api and give users the ability to work around these types of issues to meet their specific needs.
In our case we're using the paper_trail gem to track changes to a model.
since that model contains a serialized attribute we record a change even if users just open the form and hit submit, but don't make  a change.
This is undesirable, but trivial enough that I'm just going to live with it.
If I had the ability to explicitly tell the model that the attribute has not changed I'd just do that.
Thanks!

title: New default ordering of `first` breaks `group` queries
body: As of Rails 4, calling `first` on an ActiveRelation adds `ORDER BY id ASC` to your query, In additionto the old `LIMIT 1`.
but this breaks queries with a `GROUP BY` expression, e.g.

this one:

    user.select("COUNT(*)").group(:role_name).first

I get this error from Postgres:

    select  COUNT(*) FROM "users"  GROUP BY role_name  ORDER BY "users".

"id" ASC LIMIT 1
    ActiveRecord::StatementInvalid: PG::Error: ERROR:  column "users.id" must appear in the GROUP BY clause or be used in an aggregate function

here is a workaround if anyone else is hitting the same problem:

    user.select("COUNT(*)").group(:role_name).order(nil).first

but it'd be nice if `first` could detect whether there is a `GROUP BY` clause, and if so then not add `ORDER BY`.
If you don't want the order use `take`
`take` is the old behavior of the `first`
That's great; thanks!
Rails 4 looks great btw; thank you for all your work on it.

title: Windows: fix lstat
body: Currently does the same as stat.
since windows lacks a definition for S_IFLNK we probably need to add libuv constants for this (like UV_S_IFLNK).
Also, we may need to define uv_stat_t.
On unix these could be redefined as their native counterparts.
@bnoordhuis agree?
The implementation can be mostly the same as fs__stat except that the file should be opened with the FILE_FLAG_OPEN_REPARSE_POINT flag specified.

Then in the returned struct we should check if it is a reparse point, and if it is we do this:

use GetFileInformationByHandleEx to figure out if the reparse tag is a symlink or not.

- If it is a symlink, set the UV_S_IFLNK flag
- It it is not a symlink, use normal fs__stat to traverse the reparse point.
> @bnoordhuis agree?
Yes.
I think it is more conveniente to use NtQueryInformationFile with FileAllInformation.
This is also what GetFileInformationByHandle does.
NtQueryInformationFile will just tell us what the reparse tag is.
GetFileInformationByHandle also calls ZwQueryVolumeInformationFile, which I think we might as well just skip.

title: Avoid Using Mules For Native implementation Dispatches
body: We shouldn't need the mules when using the native implementation since our impl only wraps them anyways.
This will also future-proof us and allow for the use of native fragments in conjunction with support fragments (e.g., a `PreferenceFragment`).
since `FragmentActivity` will return the proper value post-HC we also do not need the mules for aggregating the callback results.

printf("CBlock::WriteToDisk() : Truncated block file %s (new size: %u bytes)\n", std::string.c_str(), uint64 &);
Result: "CBlock::WriteToDisk() : Preallocated C:\Bitcoin\testnet\blk0001.dat bytes for block file 2130706432" -> good 
printf("CBlock::WriteToDisk() : Truncated block file %u (new size: %s bytes)\n", uint64 &, std::string.c_str());
Result: "CBlock::WriteToDisk() : Preallocated 2130706432 bytes for block file (null)" -> bad I can't explain, but the uint64 before the reference to a std::string works, reverse order and the std::string displays as (null).
Can a dev try to reproduce this or has an idea?
This is an occurence in an own-build, so perhaps not a global problem!
Is %u the right format character for an int64?

I don't think so -- we have these:

util.h:

    #if defined(_MSC_VER) || defined(__MSVCRT__)
    #define PRI64d  "I64d"
    #define PRI64u  "I64u"
    #define PRI64x  "I64x"
    #else
    #define PRI64d  "lld"
    #define PRI64u  "llu"
    #define PRI64x  "llx"
    #endif
%u is unsigned integer, usually 32 bits.
uint64 obviously is 64.
So you push a 64-bit value on the stack,, but %u only consumes the first 32 bits of it (which, if the the number is less than 2^32, is the right value).
It leaves the higher part to be interpreted as a string pointer, though.
I knew it's a 64 bit value, what I didn't know was that we have a %"PRI64u" define.
So %llu should be fine.
Will try and report back, thanks!
@sipa is right, what you see is consistent with little-endian.
This is, BTW, why people concerned with type-safety hate `printf`.
Some compilers will warn you for these mistakes  with -Wformat.
Great, now it works and thanks for that quick help -> closed!
No, %llu is not fine.
uint64_t is not guaranteed to be the same as unsigned long long.
just use PRI64u.
@sipa: That's what I did, thanks again.

Perhaps there is an issue with `Symfony\Component\Locale\tests\testCase::isSameAsIcuVersion()`, as it's the common factor for all of the Brazilian currency tests.
I'm not sure what might be causing the first date test failure.
My INI configuration has `date.timezone = "America/New_York"`, but I don't think the test should require a UTC timezone.
@jmikola Can you please run the Locale tests in this way?

php src/Symfony/Component/Locale/Resources/data/build-data.php
    export use_INTL_ICU_DATA_VERSION=true
    phpunit src/Symfony/Component/Locale/tests

We're shipping with ICU 49.1.2 data now, so it is needed to build the data for yours ICU version (ext/intl) before running the tests.
@eriksencosta: That resolved the Brazilian currency tests, although the date test still fails.
Is the necessity of `build-data.php` documented anywhere?
I either missed it, or we should probably add it somewhere :)
@jmikola Yes, it's documented in the component readME file.
Yes, I need to look this date failing test case.
What is your environment and PHP timezone?

```
$ uname -a
Linux honeydew 3.2.0-29-generic #46-Ubuntu SMP Fri Jul 27 17:03:23 UTC 2012 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

$ php -v
PHP 5.4.4-4~precise+1 (cli) (built: Aug  6 2012 13:01:46) 
Copyright (c) 1997-2012 The PHP Group
Zend Engine v2.4.0, Copyright (c) 1998-2012 Zend Technologies
```

Timezone is "America/New_York".
Thanks.
@jmikola Can you please paste here the output of the `icuinfo` command?

$ which icuinfo
    $ /usr/bin/icuinfo

```
$ which icuinfo
/usr/bin/icuinfo

$ icuinfo 
<ICUINFO>
International Components for Unicode for C/C++
 Copyright (C) 2011, International Business Machines Corporation and others.
All Rights Reserved.

Compiled-Version: 4.8.1.1
Runtime-Version: 4.8.1.1
Compiled-Unicode-Version: 6.0
Runtime-Unicode-Version: 6.0
Platform: U_LINUX
Build: x86_64-pc-linux-gnu
C compiler: gcc
C++ compiler: g++
ICUDATA: icudt48l
Data Directory: 
ICU Initialization returned: U_ZERO_ERROR
Default locale: en_US
CLDR-Version: 2.0.1
Default converter: UTF-8
Default TZ: US/Eastern
TZ data version: 2011k
Plugin file is: /usr/lib/icu/icuplugins48.txt
</ICUINFO>
```
Thanks @jmikola.
I'll investigate that.
PHP 5.4.4 changed the default behavior for the IntlDateFormatter regarding the default timezone to use.
The problem here is that ICU uses the system's timezone while PHP uses the timezone set in its `php.ini` file.

I need to find a way that works on Windows and *nix to get the system timezone since this feature was removed from [date_default_timezone_get()](http://php.net/manual/en/function.date-default-timezone-get.php) in PHP 5.4.0.
I believe this is now fixed by #6109 and can be closed.

title: java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: scala.runtime.RichLong.compare(J)I
body: i create a project following the link: http://www.fisharefriends.us/blog/2011-09-21-scala-plus-sbt-plus-finagle-plus-scalatest-plus-spring/, but i modify the version of sbt and scala, the version of sbt is 0.11.2 and the version of scala is 2.9.1.
I run the compile command in sbt, it works fine, and i run the 'run' EchoServer command in the sbt, it works fine too.

but i run the EchoClient, it throws an exception: java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: scala.runtime.RichLong.compare(J)I

java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: scala.runtime.RichLong.compare(J)I
        at com.twitter.util.Duration.compare(Time.scala:350)
        at com.twitter.util.Duration.compare(Time.scala:317)
        at scala.math.Ordered$class.$greater(Ordered.scala:46)
        at com.twitter.util.Duration.$greater(Time.scala:317)
        at com.twitter.finagle.builder.ClientBuilder.com$twitter$finagle$builder$ClientBuilder$$buildPool(ClientBuilder
scala:619)
        at com.twitter.finagle.builder.ClientBuilder$$anonfun$12.apply(ClientBuilder.scala:703)
        at com.twitter.finagle.builder.ClientBuilder$$anonfun$12.apply(ClientBuilder.scala:681)
        at scala.collection.Traversablelike$$anonfun$map$1.apply(Traversablelike.scala:194)
        at scala.collection.Traversablelike$$anonfun$map$1.apply(Traversablelike.scala:194)
        at scala.collection.LinearSeqOptimized$class.foreach(LinearSeqOptimized.scala:59)
        at scala.collection.immutable.List.foreach(List.scala:45)
        at scala.collection.Traversablelike$class.map(Traversablelike.scala:194)
        at scala.collection.immutable.List.map(List.scala:45)
        at com.twitter.finagle.builder.SocketaddressCluster.mkFactories(Cluster.scala:49)
        at com.twitter.finagle.builder.ClientBuilder.internalBuildFactory(ClientBuilder.scala:681)
        at com.twitter.finagle.builder.ClientBuilder.build(ClientBuilder.scala:789)
        at EchoClient$.main(EchoExample.scala:25)
        at EchoClient.main(EchoExample.scala)
        at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
        at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(Unknown Source)
        at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(Unknown Source)
        at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Unknown Source)
It sounds like perhaps you're using the 2.8.1 artifacts?

2.9.1 are published with the "_2.9.1" suffix, thus you need:

    "com.twitter" % "finagle-core_2.9.1" % ...

etc.
@mariusaeriksen - left you an email at your @monkey.org email... could you please reply to me there?
@danielschonfeld just did.
sorry about the delay!

What OS are you on, and what OpenSSL are you using?
since Rails is pure ruby, it should not segv.
So this is either a bugin Ruby, or more likely, a bugwith your Ruby's interaction with openssl.
I'm on OS X lion, running Ruby 1.9.3 through RVM.
This was a pretty basic Rails 3.1.3 app.
and I haven't done any sort of setup with OpenSSL (the app won't run under SSL in production either)
That's why you're getting the error then.
If you haven't setup OpenSSL then ` :enable_starttls_auto => true` isn't going to work.
Try it it without that and see if it works
Tried it to the exact same behavior.
I did a pkg install openssl in rvm then reinstalled ruby 1.9.3 using the openssl option, and now everything's working great.

title: getJSON not executed by phantomjs
body:
_**[derth...@googlemail.com](http://code.google.com/u/109876239849788616589/) commented:**_
> <b>Which version of PhantomJS are you using?
Tip: run 'phantomjs --version'. 1.8.1 > > What steps will reproduce the problem? 1.

create a JS with a getJSON callback function(data)
> 2.

Within this function do console.log or use the data
> 3. data will be empty and console.log is not executed
> 
> <b>What is the expected output?
What do you see instead? Expected: Function should be executed > Instead: Everything before and after the function is executed, but nothing inside it (maybe because it's a callback function?)
> When I use the same code with a real web browser, it works.
With phantonjs, it doesn't.
:star2:   **1** people had starred this issue at the time of migration.

_**[ariya.hi...@gmail.com](http://code.google.com/u/103266860731871773002/) commented:**_
> dodata() is outside the page context, this can't work.
Please read the documentation in details and understand the concept of "jailed" (sandboxed) page context.

_**[derth...@googlemail.com](http://code.google.com/u/109876239849788616589/) commented:**_
> No it also doesn't work when I put my Highchart inside the callback function.
And it doesn't work when I just place a context.log("..."); inside this function.
I tried many things but it seems nothing is executed inside this function.

_**[ariya.hi...@gmail.com](http://code.google.com/u/103266860731871773002/) commented:**_

> 	res = jQuery.getJSON("http://www.mysite.de/api/GetChart.php?callback=?

title: added pyp formula
body: added a formula for Pyed Piper (pyp).

> Pyp is a linux command line text manipulation tool similar to awk or sed, but which uses standard python string and list methods [...]

Currently pulling the single Python executable (no dependencies) from my unofficial github mirror.
Reference: http://code.google.com/p/pyp/
see comments in #7248.
Thanks for the feedback.

So two follow ups:

 1.
Using `#!/usr/bin/env` would essentially solve the python interpreter issue.
The repository mirror is currently under my control, as is the proposed brew formula.
Assuming pypi won't be merging pyp any time soon, is this a definitive WONTfix on the formula?
Don't use a mirror, pull the file from the upstream SVN but pull from the specific revision that defines version 2.1
Unfortunately the upstream SVN repo has no tags or release branches.
I have no problem tagging my git mirror, and pointing to the release tags insteadof HEAD.
would that suffice?

You can use the revision number as the tag:

`url "http://svn" :revision => "1234"`
Squash to a single commit.
(M) @jacknagel - squashed.
@adamv - please consider pulling.
thanks!
Hey Y'all I want this as well!
Please accept this pull request!
What, no man page?
Great thanks y'all!

title: fs: fix warning on OSX
body: OSX has no public API for fdatasync.

And as pointed in `man fsync(2)`:

  For applications that require tighter guarantees about the integrity of
  their data, Mac OS X provides the F_FULLFSYNC fcntl.

The F_FULLFSYNC
  fcntl asks the drive to flush all buffered data to permanent storage.

Applications, such as databases, that require a strict ordering of writes
  should use F_FULLFSYNC to ensure that their data is written in the order
  they expect.
Please see fcntl(2) for more detail.
Done
Landed with some nudges in 23dc564.
Thanks, Fedor.

title: Correct offlineimap formula name
body: see comments on issue #1243.
As far as I can tell a pull request wasn't made, so I've renamed it here and added an alias to the old name.
It would probably be better to just add an alias with the correct name; renaming the formula will cause other issues.
Edit: I don't know if it would _actually_ break things, but I'm still wary about renaming formula, and the alias is already there anyway.

I have had this issue happen to me personally.
I have not -found- a true fix but a workaround if your willing.
(M) That error is a conflict with another installed formula (not sure which one).
(M) I have gotten around this by moving all of the folders inside cellar to the trash or another folder temporarily, then retry installing git and then move the files back to the cellar afterwards.
Its not a true fix but it will get git to build.

here is my list of installed formulas:
http://gist.github.com/323307

I also verified build failure; uninstalled git and tried to install again and received above error.
Build works on clean cellar.
here is a gist of build failing and then succeeding after I moved everything in Cellar to temporary folder then tried build.
http://gist.github.com/323314
the-kenny can you gist your installed formula?
I get the same failure with the most current Git formula.
I moved the contents of /usr/local/Cellar to another directory, then tried `brew install git` again.
Still got the same failure.
Sorry for taking so long to respond; I -found- the problem some minutes after I posted this issue, and just forget about it.
The problem was a self-built version of libiconv in /usr/local, which for some reason wasn't built for x86_64.
Deleting this version in /usr/local fixed everything.
Cool.

I think it is likely something deeper though as we've had quite a few dupe tickets for this since about Git 1.7.

al3x could you gist the build output?
As I recently changed the Git formula to show verbose build output and that should help.

In the meantime if you really need a working git I recommend downgrading the formula to 1.6.2: 

    git reset ab7c4fa Library/Formula/git.rb
    brew install git
I ended up uninstalling everything I had installed.
The current Git forumla then built just fine.
Something else I had previously installed must have caused the iconv issue.
Any of the proposed solutions here didn't work for me.

When I tried 'git reset' command, I received:
    Unstaged changes after reset:
    M	Library/Formula/git.rb
Then tried to install git again, same iconv error.
Also, cleaning up Cellar didn't help (same error for a brand new git installation)
Sorry you should do a --hard reset.
We'll close this when we have the checks from brew doctor committed.
should brew doctor check for "/opt/lib/libiconv.
*.dylib" or something?
"brew doctor" is in place, and we can add more checks there if "find stray dylibs" isn't enough.
Closing this issue.

title: 64-bit Octave 3.6.1 compile fails
body: I am trying to compile Octave as a 64-bit binary in order to create 8-bit integer arrays with more than 2^32 elements.
As an experiment I just added the --enable-64 flag in the brew file under compile options.
Predictably, when compiling this resulted in an error.
Note that I tested the vanilla Octave build and this went brilliantly, thank you for making this so easy.
I would be happy to assist in fixing this bugor series of bugs but I have absolutely no idea where to get started.
attached are the 3,000 line console log and the 100,000 line configuration log files produced during the build.
Any help at all would be appreciated!
https://gist.github.com/2411695

You did pretty good so far helping us debugthis, but you could also read the wiki and do the other things it mentions,
https://github.com/mxcl/homebrew/wiki/Reporting-Bugs specifically we need the output of your `brew --config` and `brew doctor`.

The next steps if you want to take a shot at understanding this, are to scan your console log for the word `error:` and eventually take a look at what Macports and Fink do, in case this is a well known issue.
I saw from your console log that you are running a 32bit Snow Leopard, even though you have a 64bit cpu.
That's not necessarily a problem, but when you told it to `--enable-64` it is possible that you told it you want 64bit only.

(M) An example of that possibility is your linker environment flag,

    LDFLAGS: -L/usr/local/Cellar/readline/6.2.2/lib -L/usr/local/Cellar/texinfo/4.13a/lib -arch x86_64 -L/usr/X11/lib

has that `-arch x86_64` but it doesn't have `-arch i386` also.
I'm not saying I'm right that this is the the problem, but it's a little strange.
A way to investigate further if this is having any effect is to use `file` or `lipo` to examine the `liboctave.dylib` that was created.

If you brew like this:

    brew install -vd octave

the Homebrew will drop into a shell after it errors leaving all the source code for you to examine.

At that point you would locate the `liboctave` that is in some subdirectory (could be a .libs hidden one) and run one of these:

    file liboctave.dylib
    lipo -info liboctave.dylib

You would be looking to see if that library is built for just 64bit or for both it and i386.
(M) We call files built for both architectures a 'universal binary', and we expect those to build with lots of instances of:  `-arch x86_64 -arch i386` in nearly every command, both of them.
My gut feeling is you ran into a problem where octave fails_with_llvm due to bugs either in llvm or their code.
Looking at macports might help, but I'll leave that till after we get more output from you.
Wall of help :-)
Wow, I'll try to do justice to that great reply.

**Config File updates**
Firstly `brew --config` and `brew doctor` have been added to the gist below.
I identified and resolved a couple of issues from `brew doctor` so I went ahead and edited the contents of the log files as well.

https://gist.github.com/2417400

**Resolutions and New Issues**
The issue is no longer the linking problem but a (hopefully) more tractable issue with fortran and 64-bit integers.
I'll try to solve this problem in parallel but if it's acceptable I'd like to keep this ticket open for now.

**32-bit Kernel Issues**
Regarding your comment on 32-bit Snowleopard, I initially encountered this in another [project](https://github.com/rheyns/pollock-conjecture-stats/blob/74ecc26a274e9917812fdd1839ec537155b79766/pyramidal.c) of mine and it turns out that only the kernel is 32-bit and userspace programs still enjoy the benefits of 64-bit memory access.
In the version linked to memory access is important and I was successfully able to allocate arrays with more than 2^32 elements.

With `-arch i386` we get `size_t is 4 bytes long.`

This implies that we should be able to address memory structures with more than 2^32 elements (at least in C).

al:~ rheyns$ gcc test2.c 
    al:~ rheyns$ ./a.out 
    successfully allocated more than 4GB memory!

Some builtin utilities were probably built with `-arch i386`

    al:~ rheyns$ gdb
    GNU gdb 6.3.50-20050815 (Apple version gdb-1705) (Fri Jul  1 10:44:54 UTC 2011)
    Copyright 2004 Free Software -found-ation, Inc.
    GDB is free software, covered by the GNU General Public License, and you are
    welcome to change it and/or distribute copies of it under certain conditions.
Type "show copying" to see the conditions.
There is absolutely no warranty for GDB.
Type "show warranty" for details.
This GDB was configured as "x86_64-apple-darwin".

(gdb) p sizeof(sizeof(int))
    $1 = 4
Can you tell us how you got XCode-4.1 on Snow Leopard?
Did you delete that `iconv.h` that `brew doctor` was complaining about?
Did you do the `sudo chown` step in the wiki?
Did you try `brew install -vd --use-gcc octave`?
Sorry, I was busy updating the comment above.
I just renamed `iconv.h` and am rerunning with `brew install -vd --use-gcc octave` now.

This is taking a long time so perhaps a good sign...

XCode 4.1 was probably installed from a `dmg` from developer.apple.com some time before the existence of the Mac App store.
`brew search --macports octave` and `brew search --fink octave` didn't turn up anything.
Gcc is twice as slow as clang these days.
It's a pig, but I hope it works.
Can you tell from the config log what the problem with BLAS is?
Did you decide not to switch your kernel to 64bit mode?

I ask because
all your apps will try to build as 64bit then, maybe fixing BLAS.
Any update here?
It sounds like this was due to a specific machine configuration, and not a systemic issue with how Octave compiles.
Thus, I'm inclined to close this issue.
Closing.
