title: Deleting posts from 3rd party services
body: I recently wrote code that removes (aka: hides =P) posts from Facebook when they are deleted from D* (Issue #3939).
I would like to extend this functionality to the rest of the services that we integrate with.
I'm hoping I can get some technical input from the community on how best to handle the Post to Service relationship before I start.
For the Facebook fix, I had added a new column to the post table that keeps track of the facebook_id of the post.
I'm guessing we will need to keep track of separate id's for each service that a post goes out to.
Is there a better/more efficient way to keep track of these without having to add a new column to the table for each service?
Hm, we could introduce a ServicePost model that belongs to a post and a service and use that to keep track to which services a post got shared to and have a remote_id column or whatever on that.

On the other hand when doing that, the idea to display that information in the stream comes up quickly and introducing yet another table to the stream generation feels equally bad as adding a few more columns to the posts table.
We could store all of them as a serialized object in a single 'remote_ids' column in the posts table.
would eliminate the need to add a new table and would minimize the number of columns we'd have to add to the posts table.
The trade-off would be that we would lose the ability to query/index/aggregate by remote_id, but I can't think of many reasons we'd need to do that.
Maybe if we wanted to add like a 'show me everything I've shared with X service' feature?
EDIT: Whoops, hit the 'close and Comment' button when I posted this.

title: Debuginfo and optimizations, what should homebrew do.
body: The problem of what homebrew should do with softwares which either provides debuginfo or can use extra optimizations (vector instruction sets, additional optimization levels ...) has been raised in https://github.com/mxcl/homebrew/pull/21664, and is also mentioned in d54d3f3.
Due to the complexity of the issue, (special instruction sets in bottle = danger ?
), (brewed software slower than non brewed software = annoying ?
), (software linked to the configuration of the build machine = unusable for release) ...
I suggest a discussion should be held to determine what to do, and at which condition.
(M) (Not all the configure scripts are clever enough to figure the right parameters)
just the current situation in superenv.
Any debugflag is filtered by superenv and removed.
Optimization level is treated the same way.
but special instructions sets and al.
(eg SSE, 3D-Now ...) pass through.
Qt formula posses a debugand release option, which isn't very useful right now because the same flags are used for debugand release.

(Or at least many significant flags are wiped out by superenv)
Hence the question.
I imagine we should just port some of the older ENV methods from stdenv into superenv (`ENV.O2`, etc).
but they should mainly exist as a courtesy to users; and be ignored by the cc wrapper when we are building a bottle.
We definitely don't want something that is too broad; the point of superenv is to provide consistency.
(M) We lose that if we let a bunch of formulae start passing arbitrary flags again.
Things in core should be built using the Homebrew default (`-Os -march=native`) unless there is a very good reason to do otherwise.
IMHO it is somewhat overkill for the current approach of build flag filtering.

To extend @GuillaumeDIDIER 's argument, sometimes a math-related library may use -O3 for better performance, while certain libraries may want to stay unstripped so that it eases debugging (or when valgrind works better).

Also, stripping all -W* will potentially overlook some programming errors, especially when upstream is developing on another system like Linux and doesn't have access to Mac, and such problems should be fixed.
Maybe worth considering.
however I agree that flag filtering should be applied when building bottles anyway.
Well ```-Os -march=native``` does not apply to -msse3 for instance.

(So no need of telling Qt ```-no-sse3 -no-3d-now```)
adding more powerful filtering for bottle could be a simple to start with.
What should be filtered out ?
Things dependent on machine architecture (eg sse to keep the same example) ?

(Though I think some sse instruction sets are actually supported on every single intel macintosh)
Optimization level or debuginfo ?
In that case some software could benefit of higher optimization levels without breaking anything, other cannot.
Perhaps we could have a few options, which are known to work well and select one in the formula.

(eg default, O2, no optimization, debuginfo ( for formula that provide debuginfo), O3 (for the just mentioned math libs (thank you for the example @manphiz )))
What of debug-and-release Qt (fortunately that isn't bottled)
I don't think bottles should ever provide debuginfo.
I also don't think Homebrew really should provide this stuff; I should have never added it to the Qt formula as it is a nasty hack.
I do think the superenv filtering approach is actually a good one; we are better judges than upstream on that compiler flags make  sense on OSX given most of our formulae are Linux-centric.
What is important is to -make  SURE- that flags in bottle keeps the bottle portable.
Well, obviously, linux centric formula don't know OSX well so I get your point.
but some formula are unix tools or cross platform tools that know OS X well, and make  less mistakes.
We need sensible defaults, but formula should be able to override that, if appropriate (eg -O3 for math libs that won't get broken by that).
Well Qt even provides a special bundle for installing the debuglibs and they are Included in the SDK.
but most probably, it is not bottle role to provide debuginfo (that takes space), unless if we provided a special bottle for people who need it (the debuginfo).

Still that would be complicated to handle, and I fear it is a dangerous path, to handle several bottle config (multiplication of bottle), though for instance having a bottle for pyside py2 and one for py3k, which could be combined when installing for both, could be useful (if PySide 's bottled)
What of the cross platform build systems (eg cmake , scons and al.)
which often deal with some of these feature themselves, with which our interference sometimes break things ?
Good point.

however (generally speaking, not just qt) if upstream is
indeed using less effective or wrong build flags, the issue should be
reported so that it can fixed upstream (if they care of course).

What I am proposing is when building formulae, superenv only fixes
Include and link path, and leaves the optimization/warning/arch flags
intact.
In case of error.

Local fix can be applied to individual
formula if needed and the issue should be reported upstream.

And of
course, all filtering should be enabled when building bottles.

On Thu, Aug 8, 2013 at 2:38 PM, Mike McQuaid <notifications@github.com> wrote:
> I don't think bottles should ever provide debuginfo.

I also don't think
> Homebrew really should provide this stuff; I should have never added it to
> the Qt formula as it is a nasty hack.

I do think the superenv filtering
> approach is actually a good one; we are better judges than upstream on that
> compiler flags make  sense on OSX given most of our formulae are
> Linux-centric.

>
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
Let's talk about specific formulae with specific issues that are being fixed.
As far as I can see the only formula we're talking about here in Qt and the only problem we have is universal builds not working with superenv.
agreed.
I digressed a little.
Will open a new issue for that matter.

On Thu, Aug 8, 2013 at 3:00 PM, Mike McQuaid <notifications@github.com> wrote:
> Let's talk about specific formulae with specific issues that are being
> fixed.

As far as I can see the only formula we're talking about here in Qt
> and the only problem we have is universal builds not working with superenv.

>
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
actually, universal build for Qt are fixed, except for the clang upstream issue.
(-Xarch_i386 -framework -Xarch_i386 QuickTime), reported as LLVM bug[16805](http://llvm.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=16805) and [QTBUG-32832](https://bugreports.qt-project.org/browse/QTBUG-32832).
The issue I opened here was meant to discuss more generally the debugissue.

It started from Qt, because it was what I was working on, but when I began working on debugand optimization, extending that to Include other formulae, I felt that it needed to be thought about more carefully.
So @manphiz wasn't digressing, this is the issue opened for general discussion.
The subject of the discussion is the approach toward debugand optimization in general, so that it can be implemented correctly in superenv.
Then, we can update each formula individually.
For Qt the only remaining problem is wether we should disable SSE3 and 3D-now, and from where we should do it.
If we disable that rom superenv/cc, it will affect all the formulae.
In my opinion, for flag refurbishing, we could use a 2-level approach.
First an arg sandbox, which filters a list of forbidden flags, in which we can poke holes from formulae, to allow -O3 for a math lib, or to allow use of special instructions.
This is done from the formulae.
Technically this could be done using a list of allowed flags, in which we check, list that can be generated, using what the formula says and extra bottle filtering.
Also, the flag for bottle builds should trigger extra filtering, to -make  SURE- the bottle remains portable.
And then, we could also add some flags explicitly, because some configure script are dumb and won't put it.
```-arch``` for universal build, or extra optimization, if it could be useful.
but this is *"how can  we filter args"*, but we also need to think about *what flags should we filter and what debuginfo, and what optimizations can be alloweded.
And thinking of -O3 for math libs, bottling a library optimized that way, might not be that a bad idea, if it doesn't break the build and installation, or cause bugs.
We would need to test that thoroughly before adding the support, but if it passes the tests then I don't see why we shouldn't deliver the best software we can deliver.

Technically, what we could have is a list of flags that we forbid, some flags that we handle ourselves, eg Include, libraries path, sysroot ..., and a list of extra flags that we remove for bottle build (eg debuginfo ...), as for filtering.
Then we could have a list of flag that we add ourselves.
but in formulae we should not add to these list directly, but use an interface.

For instance we could have ENV.max_optimization_level, ENV.min_optimization_level, ENV.allow_debug_info (these 3 simply influence filtering), ENV.set_optimization_level (also adds the needed flags), which would take a restricted list of values (:no_optimization, 1, default (space it seems), 2, 3), with perhaps a special set of method for controlling bottle build, if needed, because the first set of method would not escape bottle filtering.

We could also apply the same logic to special instruction set (eg sse, mmx, virtualization instruction (I don't think we'll often meet  this last one, but I'm sure there are intel mac that don't support these instructions)).
Arch filtering could be done the same way.

And in formulae we can also give hints to the configure script (in Qt (in the pull request fixing universal build) we don't set ENV.universal_binary (that breaks some configure tests), but allow_universal_binary, and give configure the hint with ```-arch i386 -arch x86_64```)
I still think upstream should have the ultimate control of build flags.
They should know their software best, and it is next to impossible for package maintainer to maintain such complicated configurations.
Superenv is doing a great job to restrict paths, but messing around with build flags and optimizations may be overkill and error-prone.
For instance, https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-versions/issues/187.
This is a mailing list discussion at this point, I think.
Homebrew has decided on optimisation flags since day one and this pull request is not the place we're going to change that.
Then redirect us to the right mailing list, if there is one.
I didn't know where that discussion should take place when I started it.

Date: Sat, 10 Aug 2013 23:53:09 -0700
From: notifications@github.com
To: homebrew@noreply.github.com
CC: guillaume.didier95@hotmail.fr
Subject: Re: [homebrew] Debuginfo and optimizations, what should homebrew do.

(#21770)

This is a mailing list discussion at this point, I think.
Homebrew has decided on optimisation flags since day one and this pull request is not the place we're going to change that.

—

homebrew@librelist.com
`-Os -march=native` is a good default.
We will continue to use that, I think we all agree on this.

> We need sensible defaults, [which is above's `-Os`] but formula should be able to override that, if appropriate (eg `-O3` for math libs that won't get broken by that) -- @GuillaumeDIDIER 

agreed on that one.
Porting the `--env=std` to superenv is probably good.

>  for instance having a bottle for pyside py2 and one for py3k -- @GuillaumeDIDIER 

That is not really a problem as PySide can be built (and in theory bottled) with py2 and py3 bindings.
(M) More of an issue is that different Python 2.x are not ABI compatible.
(M) For Qt and SSE/3Dnow: We are explicitly disabling them due to build issues.
(M) If we can get Qt to build with SSE/3Dnow on superenv (Xcode-only and in all cases), I am fine with removing the `"-no-3dnow" << "-no-ssse3" if superenv?` line.
A new thought: we should only be using `-O3` if it's actually benchmarked and indicates higher performance.
One of the reasons we use `-Os` is that it tends to outperform higher `-O` in practise.

For Qt, I'll check again when I'am back from holidays, but as for sse3, I had -found- that it was due to Xarch beung broken in superenv, which I fixed in my PR
I think I removed the line in my PR.

title: WP7: SignalR opens 1 connection per second, using both long polling and server sent events
body: I am using SignalR 5.1, which I got using NuGet.
The client is a Windows Phone 7 app, so it is using "SignalR.Client.WP7".
The server is hosted on IIS8.
My development machine is Windows 8, the production machine is Windows Server 2012, also using IIS8, hosted on an Azure VPC.
Both are showing the same behavior.

When I start my app, the SignalR functionality seems to work fine, but when I use Fiddler to inspect the actual data traffic I see some issues:

I continuously see 2 types of requests being made: One with transport=longPolling and one with transport=serverSentEvents
Both request types are fired to the server every 2 seconds.
I was assuming that long polling would be able to keep connections open much longer?
SignalR doesn't use Websockets, which is enabled on the server and does work with another library (Websockets4Net).
The client does submit the TryWebSockets parameter with true.
I'm especially curious about issue 1 and 2, as I'm worried that this behavior would give a heavy load on the server.
Edit: I have now also tried connecting to the same SignalR server using the JavaScript implementation.
This actually does use Websockets.
When I disable Websockets the long polling works perfectly, keeping the connection open for a long time.
You're using SignalR 0.5.1 (not sure which package version), you should use 0.5.3 if you're not.
The request every 2 seconds sound like you have some duplicate requests with the same connection id.
It could be the fallback logic messing up and if it is, you can specific a transport specifically.
WebSockets isn't supported on the .NET client.
SignalR and Fiddler:https://github.com/SignalR/SignalR/wiki/Using-fiddler-with-signalr
Experiencing the same issue as continious requests transport=serverSentEvents then two of transport=longPolling and again each couple of second.
Running the WP and AspNet samples from SignalR/samples as client and host respectively.
Basically that renders as "Reconnected", "Connected -> Reconnecting", "Reconnecting -> Connected" event sequence in application interface (maybe the order is wrong though).
Same reproduces in any combination as local dev server (IIS Express) or remote (IIS8) one, WP emulator or device.
Any ideas?
We don't support WP7 anymore.
@cspare, you've made my day, the workaround does work preventing from reconnects.
Was just confused with intercepted requests implying the long polling transport.
Now just wondering why this does not work out of box expected in up-to-date samples code.
@davidfowl, thanks for comment.

title: Can't read signed cookies in a before filter
body:
In order to give the user an identifier so he can start using the app, I wrote something like:

``` ruby
class ApplicationController < ActionController::Base
  protect_from_forgery
  before_filter :attribute_guest_id
  
  private

  def attribute_guest_id
    if cookies.permanent.signed[:guest_id].blank?

cookies.permanent.signed[:guest_id] = SecureRandom.uuid
    end
  end
end
```

but it causes ```undefined method `[]' for nil:NilClass``` errors.
My mistake.
I just noticed that `permanent` must not be used for reading.

title: Graticule should support major and minor extent.
body:
Consider the following example:

!

[](http://www.progonos.com/furuti/MapProj/Normal/ProjInt/ProjIntC/Img/Z1/mp2_SinuMollweide-s75.png)

Most of the graticule lines extend from 80°S to 80°N.
however, lines at 90° longitude extend all the way to the poles.
One way to support this functionality might be to distinguish between the *major* extent and the *minor* extent, and likewise the *major* step and the *minor* step.
The default *minor* extent could be [[-180, -80], [180, 80]], while the default *major* extent could be [[-180, -90], [180, 90]].
likewise the default *minor* step could be 22.5, and the default *major* step 90.
The implementation would need to -make  SURE- that major lines that coincide with minor lines (as will happen by default) are not duplicated in the returned lines.
fixed by #1010.

title: fix race condition when client sends immediately after connecting
body: The client is ready when the event source is opened.
That happens when the response is returned from the server.
There's a window there where the server side message bus subscription isn't setup as yet.

title: Invalid encoding and 500 error on 5.0.0-stable.
body: Hi!
I installed gitlab on Ubuntu 12.04, created new project and pushed master branch from my main workstation.
All files and commit messages and in KOI8-R, encoding parameter of every commit is “KOI8-R”.
In “File” section of project, “Last commit” info is correct encoded, but when I open, some files have text like “îÁÓÔÒÏÊËÁ”.

In “commits” section also preview text is ok, but then I open commits, part of them return 500 error (with “invalid byte sequence in UTF-8” error in log), part have wrong encoding in commit message, and some files in diff blocks have wrong encoding and some have correct encoding.
So, i can't understand the algorithm, rules of encoding.
May be you have some ideas?
After updating to 5.1.0-stable, get 500 Encoding Error every time, trying to watch commits in project
Any more details on this?
I think the problem is that there is no possibility of an explicit encoding of repository.
As I understand it, there is an attempt to automatically determine encoding by charlock holmes, but to my knowledge, there does not exist a way to ensure encoding detection.

Two possible options:
- Provide the user the ability to explicitly specify the encoding.
(M) - When encode, skip (or replace with some sign) characters that are not in utf-8.
Is this still an issue in 5.2 or latest master?
Thanks for the issue report.

Please reformat your issue to conform to the issue tracker guidelines -found- in our [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/gitlabhq/gitlabhq/blob/master/CONTRIbutING.md#issue-tracker-guidelines).
It's been at least 2 weeks (and a new release) since we heard from you.
I'm closing this issue but if you still experience this problem, please open a new issue (but also reference the old issue(s)).

-make  SURE- to also Include the necessary debugging information conforming to the issue tracker guidelines -found- in our [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/gitlabhq/gitlabhq/blob/master/CONTRIbutING.md#issue-tracker-guidelines).

title: ActiveRecord: Include usecs when quoting DateTime in PostgreSQL adapter
body: The PostgreSQL adapter has a bugwhere it fails to Include the fractional seconds when quoting DateTime values for queries or storage.

This causes loss of precision during storage, and also failure during future query operations, like so:

    f = Foo.first
    Foo.where(:created_at => f.created_at.to_datetime).first.id == f.id # false

This patch ensures the usec are sent when quoting DateTime objects (as they are for Time objects)
May you squash commits and add changelog.
/cc @pixeltrix
@pftg @pixeltrix added the changelog entry and squashed the commits.
Thanks for for the speedy response!
I wonder whether it'd make  more sense to add `usec` and `nsec` methods to `DateTime` in Active support.
(M) That way we eliminate the `respond_to?
(:usec)` and don't add the `to_time` conversion.
I did some grepping and discovered maybe https://github.com/rails/rails/issues/10855 has added `usec` and `nsec`, but it's not in a release yet.
Is that right?
Yes - sorry I forgot I'd already added it :smile:
Does the test you added fail without your change?
Nope, it passes :)  Nice to see that this is already fixed.
We can discard this change completely, or I can remove the actual code but leave the test to protect regression.
Can you update it to just the test, thanks!
Done.
Thanks!
